entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Draconic Archetype Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Draconic Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Draconic Archetype Feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Draconic Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Draconic Archetype Feature
entries: At 17th level, you gain a feature granted by your Draconic Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Draconic Archetype Feature
entries: At 20th level, you gain a feature granted by your Draconic Archetype.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Dragon
entries: Some warriors are born in the depths of a dragon’s lair where they absorb the lingering magic in the area, allowing them to channel it into their burning rage.

Most barbarian tribes who worship dragonkind usually revere them as gods for their unmatched strength and frightening auras. Barbarians who can harness their dragonkin’s powers are often regarded as the strongest of their tribes.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Ancestor
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to speak, read, and write Draconic or one other language of your choice. In addition, you’ve grown up around dragons, inheriting some of their magic. Choose chromatic, gem, or metallic. You can then choose one damage type that is associated with your chosen draconic ancestor. The damage type you choose is used by features you gain later.

entries.caption: Draconic Ancestor
rows: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison

entries: If a feature from this subclass requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Fury of The Dragon
entries: At 3rd level, you can channel draconic energy into your weapon strikes. While you're raging, the first creature you hit on each of your turns with a weapon attack takes extra damage equal to {@dice 1d6}. The extra damage is the damage type associated with your draconic ancestor.
The extra damage increases to {@dice 2d6} at 9th level and {@dice 3d6} at 16th level.

subclassFeature.name: Rage of The Dragon
entries: Also at 3rd level, when you enter your rage your body becomes riddled with dragon scales as you undergo a draconic transformation. While raging, you gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Rage Damage found on the Barbarian table, provided you are not wearing any armor.
In addition, you gain resistance to the damage type associated with your draconic ancestor while raging.

subclassFeature.name: Breath of The Raging Dragon
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can channel the draconic energies within and exhale it into a powerful magical burst. While raging when you take the Attack action on your turn, you can replace one of the attacks with an exhalation of draconic energy in either a 20-foot cone or a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide (your choice). Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw. They take {@dice 2d10} damage of the type associated with your draconic ancestor on a failed save, or half as much on a success.
At 13th level, the damage of this feature increases to {@dice 3d10} and {@dice 4d10} at 17th level.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. While you have no uses available, you can expend a use of your rage to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Wings of The Raging Dragon
entries: Starting at 10th level, when you enter your rage, or as a bonus action on subsequent turns while raging, you can furl or unfurl dragon-like wings from your body. While unfurled, your wings grant you a flying speed equal to your walking speed. If you already had a flying speed, it is increased by an amount equal to half your walking speed.

If you are wearing armor, to unfurl your wings your armor must be made to accommodate them. When your rage ends, your wings instantly become furled, causing you to fall if you were still flying when they furl.

subclassFeature.name: Frightening Rage
entries: At 14th level, when you enter your rage you create an aura of frightening power. At the start of each of their turns, every creature that can see or hear you within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw or become frightened of you for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a successful save.
A creature that succeeds their saving throw is immune to this aura’s effect for 1 hour.

subclassFeature.name: The Greatwyrm
entries: There are dragons that have ascended to near god-hood known as greatwyrms. It is no secret that dragons can bestow their powers as gifts onto other creatures, there are even dragons that are gods in the D&D multiverse that bestow their powers onto clerics as divine power.

Greatwyrms are similar in nature to these divine dragons, but on a lesser scale typically. As such, they are just as capable as bestowing power to devout followers. Some greatwyrms have cult-like followings, others give their powers to great heroes and some are even children to these great beings.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: Starting at 1st level, the greatwyrm lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

entries.caption: Expanded Spell List
rows: {@spell circle of power|PHB}, {@spell summon draconic spirit|FTD}

subclassFeature.name: Eye of Dragonsight
entries: Starting at 1st level, you have the ability to perceive echoes of yourself and your dragon patron, allowing yourself to gain the knowledge and some abilities of these echoes. When you finish a short or long rest, choose one skill or tool you lack proficiency in. You gain proficiency in that skill or tool, which lasts until you finish your next short or long rest.

As an action, you can focus your dragonsight and allow yourself to see spirits. You can see into the ethereal plane out to a range of 60 feet, as if you were under the effects of the {@spell see invisibility} spell. You can retain this sight for 1 minute or until you lose your concentration (as if you were concentrating on a spell).
You can focus your dragonsight a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Gift
entries: Also at 1st level, you have a gift from your patron that physically changes you. You gain the following benefits:

items.name: Tongue of Dragons
entries: You learn to speak, read, and write Draconic or one other language of your choice.

items.name: Draconic Spells
entries: When you damage a target with a spell, you can change the damage type to acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison.

items.name: Dragon's Wrath
entries: Once during each of your turns when you hit with an attack roll, you can deal extra damage equal to your proficiency bonus. The type of damage is determined by the attack.

subclassFeature.name: Voice of The Greatwyrm
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can channel the voice of your patron to boom through yours. As an action, you can give yourself advantage on all Charisma ability checks for the next 10 minutes. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses of it once you complete a short or long rest.
Alternatively, when you have no remaining uses of this ability you can expend a warlock spell slot to use it again.
In addition, you have advantage on saving throws made to resist being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

subclassFeature.name: Flight of The Greatwyrm
entries: Starting at 10th level, as a bonus action, you can form spectral wings and give yourself a flying speed of 60 feet that lasts for 10 minutes, during which you can hover. You can use this bonus action a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ward of The Greatwyrm
entries: At 14th level, you can use a bonus action and a warlock spell slot to cast the {@spell Primordial Ward|XGE} spell. When you cast this spell in this way, you do not need to concentrate on it and its casting time is the bonus action used for it.

Alternatively, you can cast the spell in the same way but as an action instead, doing so gives you the ability to choose a creature within 30 feet of you that you can see and give them the benefits of the spell instead of yourself.

subclassFeature.name: Magitechnician
entries: Intermingling human technologies with the magic veiling the multiverse, you are able to create products of immense power and efficiency. Your creations are the bi-product of technological advancement and the study of the arcane. With mastery of both studies, you leave your enemies awestruck and wasted by your various gadgets and devices.

subclassFeature.name: Magitech Spells
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you always have certain spells prepared after you reach particular levels in this class, as shown in the Magitechnician Spells table. These spells count as artificer spells for you, but they don't count against the number of artificer spells you prepare.

subclassFeature.name: Magitech Inventor
entries: Starting at 3rd level, choose two tools you have proficiency in. Your proficiency bonus is doubled when you make ability checks using either of the chosen tools.

In addition, you can choose two infusions among the following: {@optfeature Magitech Gadget|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, {@optfeature Magitech Attachment|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, {@optfeature Magitech Vehicle|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, {@optfeature Magitech Construct|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, or {@optfeature Magitech Tool|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}. These infusions are added to your infusions known, but do not count towards the limit of infusions known and you can infuse two additional items when you complete a long rest, but they must be an infusion chosen from this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Combative Engineer
entries: Also at 3rd level, when you attack with a magic weapon, you can use your Intelligence modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity modifier, for the attack and damage rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Magitech Gear
entries: Starting at 5th level, when you finish a long rest you can magically transform up to two non-magical weapons and one set of non-magical light or medium armor into magitech variants, thereby making them magical. You gain proficiency with the weapon if you did not have it already. When you wear a set of magitech armor, you can add your Intelligence modifier instead of your Dexterity modifier to your AC (the maximum Dexterity modifier restriction to medium armor also applies to your Intelligence modifier). You can still apply infusions to items that were transformed into magitech variants.
When you damage a target with a magitech weapon, you can change the damage type to force.

You can only have up to two magitech weapons and one set of magitech armor at any given time, and they remain as their magitech until you spend an action to dismiss the magic keeping them transformed or until you die.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Magitech Research
entries: At 9th level, you can choose one additional infusion from the list provided by your Magitech Inventor feature, count towards the limit of infusions known and you can infuse two additional items when you complete a long rest, but it must be one of the infusions chosen by this class’ subclass features.

subclassFeature.name: Magitech Energy
entries: Starting at 9th level, you’ve discovered how to draw in the magic around you and channel it into condensed energy, allowing you to use that energy in a variety of ways. You have a number of magitech energy equal to twice your Intelligence modifier. You can use magitech energy in the following ways:

items.name: Disruptive Barrier
entries: When you would be hit by an attack, you can spend 1 to 5 magitech energy as a reaction to increase your AC by 1 per magitech energy spent against the triggering attack, potentially turning a hit into a miss.

items.name: Weapon Surge
entries: As a bonus action, you can spend 1 to 3 magitech energy and channel it into one of your magitech weapons. The next time you hit with a magitech weapon, it deals an additional {@dice 1d8} of force damage per magitech energy spent.

items.name: Ability Boost
entries: When you would fail an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, you can expend 1 to 3 magitech energy to gain a +2 bonus to the roll per magitech energy spent.
You regain all expended magitech energy when you finish a long rest, or you can use a bonus action to spend a spell slot to regain an amount of magitech energy equal to the level of the spent slot.

subclassFeature.name: Magitech Mastery
entries: Starting at 15th level, you can transform magical weapons and armor into magitech variants using your Magitech Gear feature and you can even apply infusions to these items, despite them already being magical. Magitech items that you are attuned to does not count against the total number of attunement slots you have.
In addition, whenever you hit a creature with a magitech weapon, the creature takes an extra {@dice 1d8} force damage.

subclassFeature.name: The Rune Blade
entries: Not all sorcerers obtain their magic from their blood directly, sometimes it’s a magical gift granted to them later on in their life. This gift may be passed on through generations, either through their family line or as a renowned prophecy of inheritance.

subclassFeature.name: Rune Magic
entries: Your magic is drawn from the oldest forms of magic, which grants you access to certain spells. You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Rune Blade Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be an {@filter abjuration or conjuration spell from the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock;wizard|school=a,c|level=1;2;3;4;5}

entries.caption: Rune Blade Spells
rows: {@spell hex}, {@spell protection from evil and good}
{@spell circle of power}, {@spell steel wind strike|XGE}

subclassFeature.name: Runic Weapon
entries: At 1st level, you’ve discovered an ancient magical secret that allows you to form a melee weapon with runes. By performing a 10-minute ritual you can create this magical weapon. It counts as a martial melee weapon with the finesse and light properties. You are proficient with this weapon and you can use it as a spellcasting focus. It deals 1d6 damage of your choosing from bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage. You can only have one runic weapon created by this feature at a time. The damage increases to 1d8 at 6th level and 1d10 at 14th level.

Alternatively, by performing a similar 10-minute ritual, you can transform a weapon you are proficient with into a runic weapon, using its statistics instead but you can also use it as an spellcasting focus. This transformation lasts until you finish a long rest or until you die. You can perform this ritual once, regaining the ability to do so again when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Blade Runes
entries: Also at 1st level, magical runes appear on your runic weapons. Choose two of the listed runes below, you learn how to scribe these runes on your runic weapons, which you can do after you complete a long rest or when you perform the ritual to create and or transform them. You can only have one rune active at a time.

entries.name: Haug Rune
entries: This rune's magic bestows a resilience reminiscent of a hill giant. As a bonus action, you can bestow the wielder of this weapon resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks.

In addition, when you hit a creature with an attack made with this weapon, once a round you can force that creature to make a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, they are knocked prone or pushed back 5 feet (your choice).

entries.name: Ild Rune
entries: This rune’s magic gives you the fiery powers of ancient giants. As a bonus action, you can ignite the flames on this weapon changing its properties. When you damage a target with an attack made with this weapon, you can change the damage type of the weapon to fire damage.

In addition, while the rune is active, magical flames veil your body. When you are hit with a melee attack, you can spend your reaction to deal 2d6 fire damage to the attacker as the flames lash out at the creature.

entries.name: Ise Rune
entries: This rune's magic evokes a frost giant's stoic calm. As a bonus action, you can evoke a cold energy onto this weapon changing its properties. When you damage a target with an attack made with this weapon, you can change the damage type of the weapon to cold damage.

In addition, while the rune is active provided you aren’t wearing medium or heavy armor, you gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of +1) as magical ice forms around your body as a protective shell.

entries.name: Rune of Dragon's Might
entries: This rune’s magic contains the powerful might of dragons. As a bonus action, you can evoke this magic and empower yourself with it. You have advantage on Strength-based attack rolls, Strength ability checks, and Strength saving throws.
In addition, your movement speed is increased by 10 feet and moving out of a creature’s reach does not provoke opportunity attacks.

entries.name: Rune of Ancient Horrors
entries: This rune’s magic contains the ancient horrors of aberrant creatures. As a bonus action you can release this rune’s magic changing your weapon’s properties. When you damage a creature with this weapon, you can force that creature to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, they become frightened of you for one minute. They can repeat their save at the end of each of their turns, ending the effect on a success.

In addition, while this rune is active when you are hit by a melee attack by a creature, you can spend your reaction to release a tendril from the far realm to grab onto the attacker. They become grappled for 1 minute. They can use an action to attempt to escape the grapple with an escape DC equal to your spell save DC.

entries.name: Uvar Rune
entries: Using this rune’s magic, you can evoke the power of storms. As a bonus action, you can change the properties of your weapon using this rune’s magic. When you damage a target with an attack made with this weapon, you can change the damage type of the weapon to lightning damage.

In addition, while this rune is active when you would be hit by a melee attack by a creature, you can spend your reaction and roll a d6. You can reduce the attack roll by the number rolled on the d6, potentially turning a hit into a miss.

Alternatively, using the same bonus action you use to activate these runes, or a bonus action on subsequent turns, you can give the benefits of that rune to different creature that you can see within 30 feet of you for 1 minute, after which the rune returns back to you. You cannot gain the benefits of that rune again until that creature loses the given rune. You can use a bonus action to switch the target of that rune to a different creature, or switch it back to yourself.
When you give these runes to another creature, the runes appear on one of their weapons that they are holding.

You can activate your runes a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Alternatively, when you have no remaining uses of your runes, you can expend a spell slot of any level to regain one use of your runes. Any rune that has been activated remains active for 1 hour or until you dismiss them (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Additional Blade Runes
entries: At 6th level, you learn two additional runes from your Blade Runes feature.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. Moreover, you can cast one of your cantrips in place of one of those attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Blade Runes
entries: At 14th level, you learn two additional runes from your Blade Runes feature.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Rune Magic
entries: Also at 14th level, you can have two runes active at a time instead of one. Also, as a bonus action on your turn you can flare a burst of runic energy by expending 3 sorcery points. Until the end of your next turn, you can activate one of your inert runes regardless of how many you have active, but only on yourself.
In addition, when you hit with a weapon attack using a runic weapon, you add a bonus to the damage roll equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of +1).

subclassFeature.name: Runic Master
entries: Starting at 18th level, you can have 3 runes active at a time. Also, you can use a bonus action to immediately end one of the effects of your active runes to regain an expended spell slot of 3rd level or lower.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Tempest
entries: Born with the might of dragons, elementals, giants, or other similar stormborn creatures, you follow a monastic tradition that teaches you to harness the power of a raging storm that brews within you. When you focus your ki, you can align yourself with the storm inside you and bend them to your will, using them as an extension of your body.
Many monks of this tradition tattoo their bodies with representations of their ki powers, commonly imagined as coiling dragons, but also as elder tempests and arcane sigils.

subclassFeature.name: Channel The Storm
entries: {@i 3rd-level Tempest Feature}

You can call upon the might of a raging tempest that lies deep within your soul. Once per round on your turn, you can add bonus lightning or thunder damage (you choose when you use this feature) to your monk weapons or unarmed strikes when you hit with them. This bonus equals your martial arts die.

subclassFeature.name: Step of the Tempest
entries: {@i 3rd-level Tempest Feature}
When you use your Step of the Wind feature, you can spend an additional ki point to increase your movement speed by an additional 10 feet until the end of the turn.

subclassFeature.name: Stormlord's Protection
entries: {@i 6th-level Tempest Feature}
You gain resistance to lightning and thunder damage.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Disciple
entries: {@i 6th-level Tempest Feature}

You can channel your inner storm into magical spells and other magical abilities. Choose one of three styles: Dragon, Giant, or Primordial. You can cast certain spells depending on your chosen style using ki points. The spell save DC is equal to your Ki Save DC and you use your Wisdom modifier for determining your spell attack bonus. You do not require material components to cast these spells, even costly ones.

entries.name: Dragon
entries: You can spend 3 ki points to cast {@spell dragon's breath|XGE} (you can only choose lightning), 4 ki points to cast {@spell lightning bolt}, or 4 ki points to cast {@spell fly}.

entries.name: Giant
entries: You can spend 3 ki points to cast {@spell augury}, 4 ki points to cast {@spell call lightning}, or 4 ki points to cast {@spell thunder step|XGE}.

entries.name: Primordial
entries: You can spend 3 ki points to cast {@spell gust of wind}, 4 ki points to cast {@spell elemental weapon} (you can only choose lightning or thunder damage), or 4 ki points to cast {@spell wind wall}.

subclassFeature.name: Stormborn's Tempest
entries: {@i 11th-level Tempest Feature}
As a bonus action you can spend a ki point to channel a powerful storm that coils around your body for 1 minute. While active, you gain the following benefits:

items: You gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed and can hover.
Whenever you deal an amount of lightning or thunder damage each creature that takes damage takes an additional amount of lighting or thunder damage equal to your proficiency bonus.
Whenever you are hit by a melee attack from a creature within 5ft of you, they take an amount of lightning or thunder damage equal to your proficiency bonus.

entries: Once your Stormborn’s Tempest ends, you cannot enter it again until you finish a long rest, or if you expend 3 ki points to regain the ability to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Grandmaster
entries: {@i 17th-level Tempest Feature}

You’ve mastered the magical power within, granting you additional spells and abilities at your disposal. As an action, you gain immunity to lightning and thunder damage for the next minute. Once you do so, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest, or you expend 3 ki points to regain a use of this feature.
In addition, depending on which style you chose at 6th level, you can cast the following spells using ki:

entries.name: Dragon
entries: You can spend 5 ki points to cast {@spell freedom of movement}, 6 ki points to cast {@spell destructive wave}, or 7 ki points to cast {@spell chain lightning}.

entries.name: Giant
entries: You can spend 5 ki points to cast {@spell storm sphere|XGE}, 6 ki points to cast {@spell steel wind strike|XGE} (the damage dealt is lightning or thunder damage instead of force), or 7 ki points to cast {@spell scatter|XGE}.

entries.name: Primordial
entries: You can spend 5 ki points to cast {@spell summon elemental|TCE} (you can only choose air), 6 ki points to cast {@spell control winds|XGE}, or 7 ki points to cast {@spell investiture of wind|XGE}.

subclassFeature.name: Summoner
entries: Draconic blood flowing through your veins may not be enough. Sometimes, you need an extra set of hands, or claws rather. In addition to draconic blood, you have a dragon’s soul intertwined with yours. Realizing the hidden power within your soul, you can call upon that soul and magically create a companion that is a manifestation of the draconic soul within you.

subclassFeature.name: Manifest Dragon
entries: Starting at 3rd level, as an action you can manifest a magical dragon to aid you in battle. It appears in an unoccupied space of your choice within 30 feet of you. The dragon is friendly to you and your companions, and it obeys your commands. When you manifest the dragon, choose one of its three types: {@creature Sea Serpent Draconic Ally|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, {@creature Drake Draconic Ally|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, or {@creature Winged Draconic Ally|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}. The choice you make determines some of its features and speeds. Each type has its own accompanying stat block where you can see its game statistics, which uses your proficiency bonus (PB) in several places. In combat, the Draconic Ally shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but the only action it takes on its turn is the {@action Dodge} action, unless you take a bonus action on your turn to command it to take another action. That action can be one in its stat block or some other action. If you are {@condition incapacitated}, the Draconic Ally can take any action of its choice, not just {@action Dodge}. You can determine the cosmetic characteristics of the dragon, such as its color or its scale texture; your choice has no effect on its game statistics.

The dragon remains until it is reduced to 0 hit points, until you use this feature to summon the dragon again, or until you die. Anything the dragon was wearing or carrying is left behind when the dragon vanishes.
Once you summon the dragon, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Manifestation
entries: At 7th level, your manifested dragon has become stronger and is a more viable asset. Its size becomes medium. If you spend 8 hours training your dragon, it can learn an additional language, but only if you know the language yourself. In addition, the Draconic Ally gains the following improvements:

items: It can make two attacks when it takes the attack action using any combination of its available attacks.
As a reaction, whenever it takes damage that it resists, it can choose to become immune to that damage type until the start of your next turn, taking none of that damage from the triggering source.
Its weapon attacks are considered magical for the purposes of overcoming non-magical resistances.
Its bite deals an additional 1d6 damage, its type corresponding to the damage you resist from your Draconic Origin.

subclassFeature.name: Shared Mind of the Drakes
entries: At 10th level, you and your draconic ally have an inseverable connection, maximizing your versatility in combat. You no longer require a bonus action to command your draocnic ally while you are not incapacitated as you can mentally command it telepathically (no action required).

In addition, your draconic ally is immune to any effect that would send it to another plane of existence unless it wishes to be sent there, and you have advantage on saving throws against being banished or unwillingly sent to another plane of existence.
Both you and your draconic ally are immune to being possessed while your draconic ally is manifested and is within 30 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Superior Manifestation
entries: At 14th level, your manifested dragon has reached its adulthood and is now a fierce foe in combat. Its size becomes large. In addition, the Draconic Ally gains the following improvements:

items: The extra damage for its bite increases by 1d6 (for a total of 2d6 extra damage).
Its movement speeds are increased by 10 feet.
The DC for its special actions increases by 2.

subclassFeature.name: Mournful Sacrifice
entries: At 17th level, if you were to die by any means while your dragon is manifested, you can instantly destroy your manifestation and expend all remaining uses of your Manifest Dragon feature to avoid dying. When you do so, you are brought to your feet at 1 hit point instead.
Sacrificing your dragon in this way leaves a scar on your magical ability to manifest it.

The first time your manifested dragon is destroyed in this manner, you cannot summon it again under any circumstance for 7 days. Each time afterward increases the amount of time by an additional 7 days, up until after the third time you’ve done so. In which case, if it is destroyed in this way again, you cannot summon it again by any means. Only a wish spell can restore your ability to manifest your dragon, upon which you can use this feature once before you lose the ability to manifest it again under the same means.

subclassFeature.name: Supreme Manifestation
entries: At 20th level, your dragon has reached its peak potential and is now your most powerful ally. Its size becomes huge and deals twice as much damage to structures and objects. In addition, the Draconic Ally gains the following improvements:

items: It can make three attacks when it takes the attack action instead of two.
The extra damage for its bite increases by 1d6 (for a total of 3d6 extra damage).
The reach of all of its attacks are increased by 5 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Invoker
entries: Invokers have harnessed the powers that dwell within them, their bodies becoming more and more dragon-like as they unlock more powers. As an invoker you focus less on physical capabilities and more so on spellcasting.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you have discovered an ancient heritage of magical prowess and have gained the ability to cast spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|PHB|11} for the {@filter wizard spell list|spells|class=Sorcerer}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn two cantrips of your choice from the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|class=sorcerer}. You learn an additional sorcerer cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Invoker Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your sorcerer spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell shield} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell shield} using either slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher
entries: You know three 1st-level sorcerer spells of your choice.

The Spells Known column of the Invoker Spellcasting table shows when you learn more sorcerer spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be an abjuration or evocation spell of your choice, and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.
The spells you learn at 8th, 14th, and 20th level can come from any school of magic.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the sorcerer spells you know with another spell of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your sorcerer spells, since you learn your spells through supernatural powers. You use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a sorcerer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

subclassFeature.name: Invoke Energy
entries: At 3rd level, you have a pool of Invoke Energy equal to twice your proficiency bonus, you regain spent invoke energy after a long rest. You learn two invocations that you can spend invoke energy and a bonus action to use them:

entries.name: Draconic Arms
entries: By spending 1 invoke energy, you morph your arms and hands into dragon-like appendages. You gain a natural weapon in the form of claws. These claws use strength for your attack and damage rolls and deal 1d10 slashing damage on hit. You can make an attack using these claws as part of this bonus action. This invocation lasts for 1 minute, after which your appendages return to normal.

entries.name: Draconic Legs
entries: By spending 1 invoke energy, you morph your legs and feet into dragon-like appendages. Your movement speed increases by 10 ft and you can take the dash action as a bonus action. You can take the dash action as part of this bonus action. This invocation lasts for 1 minute, after which your appendages return to normal.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Invocations
entries: At 7th level you can choose one of the following invocations to learn, you learn another invocation at 15th and 20th levels:

entries.name: Draconic Build
entries: As an action, you can spend 2 invoke energy to morph your torso into a more draconic-like one. The scales you have become more defined and you become more durable. Your armor class increases by 2 and you gain 10 temporary hit points. If you are hit with a melee attack while you have these temporary hit points, the attacker takes 10 points of damage. This damage is correspondent to the damage you resist from your Draconic Origins. This invocation lasts for 1 minute, or until you lose these temporary hit points, after which your torso returns to normal. You can spend an additional 2 invoke energy to increase the temporary hit points and damage by 10, but the duration of the invocation is halved.

entries.name: Draconic Eyes
entries: As a bonus action, you can spend 2 invoke energy to morph your head into a dragon’s head. During which time your darkvision is increased by 60 ft and you gain a blindsight of 10 ft. You can also see into the ethereal plane and see invisible creatures and objects. They appear as if they were ethereal outlines. This invocation lasts for 1 minute, after which your head returns to normal. You can spend an additional 2 invoke energy to double the range of this increase, but the duration of the invocation is halved.

entries.name: Dragonfire
entries: As a bonus action you can spend 2 invoke energy, dragonfire erupts from a weapon you choose. That weapon deals an additional 1d6 damage, this damage corresponds to the damage you resist from your Draconic Origins. This invocation lasts for 1 minute, or until you end it as a bonus action. You can make a single weapon attack as part of this bonus action. You can spend 2 additional invoke energy to boost the dragonfire’s damage by an additional d6, but the duration of the invocation is halved.

subclassFeature.name: Invocation Replenishment
entries: Starting at 10th level, as a bonus action you can spend a spell slot to regain an amount of spent invoke energy equal to the spell slot’s level. You have a number of uses of this feature equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses after a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Adept Invocations
entries: At 14th level, whenever you would spend invoke energy to boost an invocation, you can choose not to spend the extra energy and still gain the boost. You can do so once, and regain the ability to do so after a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Invoke Arcane
entries: At 17th level, you add your spellcasting ability modifier to the damage of your spells. In addition, you can spend any number of invoke energy to re-roll the same number of damage dice for a spell that deals damage. You must use the new result, even if it is lower than the original.

subclassFeature.name: Invocation Mastery
entries: At 20th level, when you roll initiative with no invoke energy, you regain 4. In addition, when you finish a short rest you replenish half of your invoke energy.
Also, whenever you use your action or bonus action to spend invoke energy, you can immediately cast a spell with the same casting time as the action you used. You can only do so once per round.

subclassFeature.name: Runic Scribe
entries: With the ancient power of draconic runes, these dragon warriors tattoo themselves with unwieldy magic. They learn these ancient runes as they grow stronger and are passed on to them from the knowledge of their ancestors. Awaken the truths behind your draconic origins and learn the ancient ways.

subclassFeature.name: Runic Tattoos
entries: Starting at 3rd level, magic runes appear on your person. These runes represent an ancient dialect of old draconic. If it is relevant for your campaign, you learn of the oldest form of draconic, predating the one currently being used. These runes hold significant power represented by long forgotten old magicks.
Choose two of the following runes:

entries.name: Rune of Power
entries: You’ve harnessed the power of the old magicks and can release outward a blast of arcane energy. You learn the Eldritch Blast cantrip and can cast it using Charisma as your spellcasting ability modifier, only instead of force damage, it deals the damage corresponding to the damage you resist from your Draconic Origin. You also add your spellcasting ability modifier to the damage of this cantrip. Instead of green eldritch energy, the beam takes the form of wispy dragon-like flames more akin to a dragon’s breath weapon.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune. Any time after you cast the Eldritch Blast cantrip while the boon is invoked, one of the beams deals an additional 1d10 damage. This boon lasts for 1 hour, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Rune of Knowledge
entries: You’ve gained a rune that grants you knowledge of the ancient world. During a short rest or long rest, you can spend 10 minutes meditating, reminiscing of the past. When you do so, you can learn of old techniques used for modern items. You gain proficiency in one tool or skill of your choosing. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses this tool or skill. You lose proficiency in this skill if you use this feature again.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune, granting you a boon of untapped knowledge. While the boon is invoked, each time you roll an ability check that doesn’t add your proficiency bonus using Intelligence, you add half of your proficiency bonus to that check. This boon lasts for 1 hour, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Rune of Draconic Weaponry
entries: Instead of being scribed on your person, you can scribe this rune onto a weapon of your choosing. That weapon becomes enhanced by the rune’s ancient magic, allowing it to take a more draconic-like appearance riddled with scales.

The weapon becomes magical for the purposes of overcoming non-magical resistances if it wasn’t magical already. In addition to the weapon’s normal damage, it also gains a bonus 1d4 damage corresponding to the damage type you resist from your Draconic Origins. You can only apply this bonus once per round. This bonus damage increases to a 1d6 at 5th level, a 1d8 at 11th, and a 1d10 at 17th. You can only have one weapon inscribed with this rune’s magic at a time.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune, granting you a boon of untapped strength. While the boon is invoked, every round you have advantage on your first weapon attack made with a weapon etched with this rune. This boon lasts for 1 hour, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Rune of Arcane Initiation
entries: You’ve learned how to create a magical tattoo that holds a spell inside of it. Choose a 1st level spell from the sorcerer spell list. You can cast that spell as many times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Casting the spell requires no material components nor do you need to expend a spell slot. When you finish a long rest, you can choose a different 1st level spell from the sorcerer spell list to apply to the tattoo. The spell you cast using this rune uses Charisma as your spellcasting ability.

As an action, you can invoke the latent power of the rune granting you a powerful magical aura. Any spell you cast for the next minute is treated as if it were one level higher. When you invoke the latent power of this rune, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Rune of Enlargement
entries: As a bonus action, you can become one size larger for one minute. While enlarged in this way, you add a bonus 1d4 damage to your weapon attacks once per round. You can enlarge yourself in this way a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expened uses when you finish a long rest. If you try to become larger in a space you cannot fit in, you remain your current size.
As an action after you’ve used this rune,  you can invoke the latent power of this rune, becoming one size larger and adding an additional 1d4 damage to your weapon attacks once per round.

subclassFeature.name: Advanced Runic Power
entries: Starting at 7th level, you’ve begun to delve more into your runic arts, learning more and more of the ancient ways. Choose one of the following runes to learn:

entries.name: Rune of Recovery
entries: You’ve etched a tattoo of old magicks capable of mending wounds. As an action you touch a creature, they regain 1d10 + your Charisma modifier hit points and are cured from one disease or poison afflicting them. You have a number of uses of this rune equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses after a short or long rest.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune, granting you a boon of health. While the rune is invoked, you have advantage on saving throws made to resist poison and disease and you restore a number of hit points equal to your proficiency bonus at the start of each of your turns, so long as you have at least 1 hit point. This boon lasts for 1 minute, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Rune of Blustering Winds
entries: A magic tattoo appears on your back, resembling runes in the shape of dragon-like wings. Whenever you take the dash action, you do not provoke opportunity attacks and you ignore the effects of difficult terrain. As a reaction, whenever a ranged weapon attack would hit you, you can impose disadvantage on that attack, potentially causing it to miss as you summon forth a powerful gale from the palm of your hands.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune, granting you a boon of immense speed enough to lift you off your feet. While the rune is invoked, you have a flying speed of 30 ft and you can hover. If you do not have a flying speed, whether it be natural or provided by magic, you cannot ascend any higher than 30 ft or you start falling. If you already have a flying speed, it is increased by 30 ft. This boon lasts for 1 minute, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Rune of Foresight
entries: A rune appears over your forehead, representing a third eye, as a bonus action you can take a defensive stance on your turn so long as you have not moved more than half of your movement speed. While in this defensive stance, you reduce any incoming damage by half as you pivot away from the full force of it. This has no effect on spells or magical effects that fully envelops your space, nor does it reduce psychic damage.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune, granting you a boon of true foresight. While the rune is invoked, you have advantage on Wisdom (Insight) checks and as a reaction if you were to be hit by a weapon attack that is not a critical hit, you can avoid the attack entirely. This boon lasts for 1 minute, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Rune of Spell Mastery
entries: You’ve learned how to create a magical tattoo that holds a spell inside of it. Choose a 1st level spell from the sorcerer spell list. You can cast that spell as many times as you want, requiring no material components or expending a spell slot. When you finish a long rest, you can choose a different 1st level spell from the sorcerer spell list to apply to the tattoo. The spell you cast using this rune uses Charisma as your spellcasting ability

Once when you cast the spell from this rune, you can invoke the latent power of this rune and treat the spell as if it were cast as a 2nd level spell. Once you invoke the power of this rune, you cannot do so again until after you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Runic Warrior
entries: Starting at 10th level, your attunement to your runes has given you an unnatural resistance against magical effects. You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects. In addition, spell attacks have disadvantage against you if you are within 15 ft of the caster.

subclassFeature.name: Runic Replenishment
entries: At 14th level by spending half of your hit dice during a short rest, you can replenish the usage of invoking latent power for one of your runes. Once you do so, you cannot do so again for that rune until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Runes
entries: At 17th level, choose any two rune options from 3rd or 7th level. Both runes do not have to be from the same list of runes. You learn how to scribe those two runes.

subclassFeature.name: Runic Mastery
entries: At 20th level, you now have 2 uses for invoking the latent power of your runes. In addition, you have learned to transfer the runic energy from one rune to another. You can disable the use of on your runes, causing the rune to go dim and lose its power, to regain an expended use of the latent power of one other rune. The disabled rune becomes active again after a long rest. Once you use this feature you cannot use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Shaman
entries: As a shaman you have learned to become one with your draconic ancestry, allowing you to temporarily attain the shape of a dragon. However, this transformative power can act as a double edged sword and can be difficult to use in tight places. Shamans tend to be more aggressive and ferocious on the battlefield, but also perceptive and wiser than other warriors.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: {@i 3rd-level Shaman feature}
You gain proficiency in two skills of your choosing from: Animal Handling, Insight, Medicine, Nature, or Survival.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Shape
entries: {@i 3rd-level Shaman feature}

Harnessing the draconic powers that dwell within you, you can transform your shape to resemble a more draconic figure. As an action you can morph your body into that of a dragon. When you take this form, the following rules apply:

items: You retain your ability scores in addition to your skill and saving throw proficiencies.
Your armor class increases by 2.
You gain temporary hit points equal to twice your dragon warrior level.
You can choose whether your items being worn or carried morph into your new form, or drop to the ground at your feet.

You retain the use of your class features provided your new form has the physical capability to do so. You do not retain the usage of your racial abilities, however any damage resistances you had do carry over, racial or otherwise.
You cannot speak or cast spells while in this form, you can however understand and read the languages you knew in your original form.

While in this form, you have natural weapons in the form of bites and claws. Each of these weapons deals 1d10 of your choice of slashing or piercing damage and you use strength or dexterity modifier  for attack and damage rolls

entries: As part of the same action you used to take this form, you can make a single melee attack using one of your natural weapons provided by this new form.

You can stay in your draconic shape for a number of hours equal to your proficiency bonus. You can revert to your normal form earlier by using a bonus action on your turn, and you automatically revert if you fall unconscious, drop to 0 hit points, or die.
You can use this feature once, after which you cannot use it again until you finish a short or long rest. You gain an additional use of this feature at 7th level, and another one at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Terraforming Form
entries: {@i 7th-level Shaman feature}

Dragons are known for transforming the environment around them using their magical prowess, you inherit said power when you take the form of these mighty mythical beasts. As an action while in your Draconic Shape, you can cause the area around you to shift and turn, transmogrifying the ground beneath you for 1 minute. You create a 20 ft radius of difficult terrain centered on you. This radius moves with you and you are immune to the effects of this difficult terrain. You can choose a number of creatures up to your proficiency bonus to be immune to the effects of this difficult terrain. Depending on the damage you gain resistance to from your Draconic Origins, one of the following effects becomes active, the effects ending when the difficult terrain returns to normal. You have a number of uses of this feature equal to your proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses after a long rest. If your effect requires a saving throw, the DC is 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Plumes of lava rise from the ground and the ground beneath you becomes volcanic-like in appearance. As a bonus action on your turn, you can make a ranged spell attack using Charisma as your spellcasting ability against a creature you can see within 60 ft of your difficult terrain. On hit, the target takes 2d6 fire damage and is on fire. At the start of each of the creatures' turns they take 5 points of fire damage. That creature, or another creature within 5 feet, can use an action to smother out the flames, ending the effect.

entries.name: Cold
entries: The ground beneath you freezes solid and becomes icy terrain. As part of the same action the turn you use your Terraforming Presence, and as an action on all subsequent turns thereafter, you can impose a Constitution saving throw against your Draconic Save DC on each creature suffering the effects of your difficult terrain. On a failed save, the targets take 2d6 cold damage and are incapacitated until the end of your next turn as frost coils around their body, incasing them in ice. On a success, they take no damage and are not incapacitated.

entries.name: Lightning
entries: A heavy lightning storm brews around you. As a bonus action on each of your turns, you can launch a bolt of lightning toward each creature suffering the effects of your difficult terrain. Each creature makes a Dexterity saving throw against your Draconic Save DC. On a failed save, they take 2d6 lightning damage, or half as much on a success.

entries.name: Acid
entries: Earthy plants, brambles, and vines rise from the ground around you. As a bonus action, you can cause plants to sprout and release a noxious gas against creatures suffering from your difficult terrain. They make a Constitution saving throw against your Draconic Save DC or take 2d6 poison damage and become poisoned on a failed save, or they take no damage and are not poisoned on a success.

entries.name: Poison
entries: Earthy plants, brambles, and vines rise from the ground around you. As a bonus action, you can cause plants to sprout and release a noxious gas against creatures suffering from your difficult terrain. They make a Constitution saving throw against your Draconic Save DC, or take 2d6 poison damage and become poisoned on a failed save, or they take no damage and are not poisoned on a success.

entries.name: Force
entries: Gravity increases in that area as amethyst grows from the earth, putting forth pressure onto that creature. As a bonus action, you put even more pressure onto creatures you choose within your difficult terrain. Affected creatures must make a Constitution saving throw or take 2d6 force damage and are prone on a failed save, or take no damage on a success and are not prone.

entries.name: Radiant
entries: The area around you glows with energy from the positive plane coming from crystals piercing through the ground. As a bonus action, affected creatures you choose must make a Constitution saving throw, taking 2d6 radiant damage and are blinded until the start of your next turn on a failed save, or no damage on a success and are not blinded.

entries.name: Psychic
entries: Glowing emeralds surface, allowing you to confuse creatures nearby. As an action, choose a creature suffering from the effects of your difficult terrain. They must make an Intelligence saving throw, taking 2d6 psychic damage and suffer from the effects of the Confusion spell until the start of your next turn on a failed save, or no damage on a success and do not suffer the confusion effects.

entries.name: Thunder
entries: Cracked sapphires scatter throughout the ground. As a bonus action, you can force creatures suffering through your difficult terrain by having the cracked sapphires slide against each other creating a powerful ear piercing noise. Each creature makes a Constitution saving throw or takes 2d6 thunder damage and is deafened on a failed save, or half as much on a success and are not deafened.

entries.name: Necrotic
entries: Topaz pillars rise from the ground filled with energy from the negative energy plane. As an action, you can force creatures suffering from your difficult terrain to make a Constitution saving throw, taking 2d6 necrotic damage and cannot gain the benefits of healing on a failed save, or takes half damage and can heal on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Draconic Form
entries: {@i 10th-level Shaman feature}

When you assume your Draconic Shape, you become a large creature. If you do not have the space to do so, you remain medium instead. Your natural weapons provided by your draconic form now deal 2d10 damage instead of 1d10 and count as magical for the purposes of overcoming non-magical resistance and immunities.
Also, your armor class increases by 4 instead of 2.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Terraforming
entries: {@i 14th-level Shaman feature}
The range of your Terraforming Form increases to 20 ft and the damage of its special actions (or bonus actions) increases by 2d6.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Spells
entries: {@i 17th-level Shaman feature}

You can now speak and cast spells while in your draconic shape. You can perform the somatic and verbal components of a spell while in your draconic shape, but you aren't able to provide material components.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Mastery
entries: {@i 20th-level Shaman feature}

When you assume your Draconic Shape, you become a Huge creature instead of large. If there is not enough space to do so, you become large instead. Once per round, you can deal an additional 1d10 damage with your natural weapons.
Whenever you roll initiative without any uses of your Draconic Shape, you regain one use.

subclassFeature.name: Skydancer
entries: Trained in the arts of aerial combat, these dragon warriors are masters of the sky and bring death from above. Soaring through the battlefield with elegance, speed, relentless, and always alert to danger. One strike is never enough.

subclassFeature.name: Skydancer Arts
entries: {@i 3rd-level Skydancer feature}
When you make a running long jump, you can replace the distance you can jump with the distance you can jump with your Lunging Attack, so long as you have the movement to cover said distance.

In addition you have a unique power dwelling inside of you. This power is represented by Skydancer Dice. You have a number of Skydancer Dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus. These dice are d4s and fuel the power of your Skydancer Arts, as detailed below. Your Skydancer dice becomes a d6 at 7th level, a d8 at 14th level, and finally a d10 at 20th level. You can use these special dice for the following Skydancer Arts:

entries.name: Skydancer Leap
entries: When you make a running long or high jump, you can roll your Skydancer Die and extend your jump distance by a number of feet equal to the number rolled. The first time you use this art, you don’t expend the Skydancer Die. All other times you use the art, you expend the die.

entries.name: Skydancer Flurry
entries: Once on each of your turns when you hit with a melee weapon attack, you can expend a Skydancer Die and roll it, adding the number rolled to the damage of the attack.

entries.name: Skydancer Assault
entries: When you take the {@action shove|PHB} action, you can roll a Skydancer Die and add the number rolled to the check. If the check is successful you shove the creature an additional 5 feet away from you or, if you knock it prone, it takes bludgeoning damage equal to the number rolled plus your strength modifier. You expend the Skydancer Die only if the check is successful.

subclassFeature.name: Lunging Attack
entries: {@i 3rd-level Skydancer feature}

Once per round, when you take the attack action, you can replace one of your attacks with a lunging attack. You can immediately jump forward a number of feet up to 10 times your proficiency bonus, or a number of feet up to your remaining movement speed, whichever is lower.

You then make an attack using a melee weapon that you are holding or an unarmed strike. If the attack hits, you deal an additional amount of the weapon’s damage equal to a number of Skydancer Dice per 10 feet you jumped as part of this lunging attack.

If a creature or object that wasn’t your original target is in the path of your lunging attack, you can either end your lunging attack early or make that creature or object the new target of your lunging attack.

subclassFeature.name: Skydancer Expertise
entries: {@i 7th-level Skydancer feature}
You gain proficiency in Athletics and Acrobatics if you didn’t already have it. Whenever you make an ability check that uses either of those skills, your proficiency bonus is doubled.

subclassFeature.name: Dance of Dragons
entries: {@i 7th-level Skydancer feature}

You can harness the potent energies within you and bring it outward. As a bonus action you can begin your Dance of Dragons which lasts for 1 minute. While your Dance of Dragons is active and you are not wearing medium or heavy armor, or wielding a shield, you gain the following benefits:

items: When you are about to be hit by an attack or fail a dexterity saving throw, as a reaction you expend a Skydancer Die to give yourself a bonus to your AC or save equal to what you roll, potentially turning that attack into a miss or turning the failure into a success.
When you make an attack roll using your Lunging Attack, the attack has advantage.
Once per round, the damage that you deal when using a Skydancer Art or a Lunging Attack gains a bonus equal to your Charisma modifier.
Your movement speed increases by 10 feet.

entries: Once you have used your Dance of Dragons, you cannot use it again until you have finished a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Sky Striker
entries: {@i 10th-level Skydancer feature}
You are a master of the skies, your Skydancer Arts become an extension of yourself giving you these Skydancer Arts that use your Skydancer dice:

entries.name: Sky Dancing
entries: As an action, you can expend a Skydancer die, roll it, and gain a magical flying speed of 40 feet and can hover for a number of minutes equal to the number rolled on the Skydancer die. If you already have a flying speed, it is increased by 20 feet.

entries.name: Sky Strike
entries: While you are flying, when you take the attack action and miss with a melee weapon attack, you can roll a Skydancer die and add it to the attack roll, potentially turning the miss into a hit. You expend the Skydancer die only if you hit with the attack.

subclassFeature.name: Skydancer Alacrity
entries: {@i 14th-level Skydancer feature}
You are granted the gift of speed and alertness from your training as a Skydancer. Your walking speed increases by 10 feet while you’re not wearing medium or heavy armor.
In addition, you can add a bonus to your initiative equal to your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Dancing Fury
entries: {@i 17th-level Skydancer feature}

You’ve honed the art of aerial combat, making you a predator of the skies. While flying, after you’ve taken the attack action you can use a bonus action to immediately make a single weapon attack using a melee weapon or an unarmed strike. If you have the effects of your Dance of Dragons active when doing so, you can make two attacks with this bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Master of the Skies
entries: {@i 20th-level Skydancer feature}

You’ve fully mastered the art of skydancing, making you a true master of the skies. You can expend a Skydancer die to regain a use of your Dance of Dragons feature. You can only do so once and cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

Your walking speed increases by 10 feet and you have a magical flying speed equal to your walking speed. If you already had a flying speed, it increases by 10 feet unless it would otherwise be slower than your walking speed. In that case, your flying speed becomes equal to your walking speed.
In addition, whenever you roll initiative without any remaining Skydancer dice, you regain 3 of them.

subclassFeature.name: Mystic
entries: Trained in the ancient arts of powerful dragons, these warriors are the closest to dragon kin in spirit. While other dragon warriors can physically morph their forms to become dragons, or even emulate the dragons themselves, the mystics are dragons by both blood and spirit. They have ancestral origins to the mighty mythical beasts and their connection to their draconic soul is rivaled only by another mystic.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Soul
entries: {@i 3rd-level Mystic feature}
Your connection to dragons is so grand, you might as well be their kin. Your creature type counts as both your original creature type and dragon.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Style
entries: {@i 3rd-level Mystic feature}

Every dragon has a different style of combat, you’ve specifically trained in one of these styles and mastered the basics of it. As you grow stronger, your mastery over this style of combat improves. Choose one of the following Draconic Styles:

entries.name: Arcane Style
entries: Many dragons have magical power that flows within them, you’ve learned to use this power to a limited degree. You learn two cantrips and one 1st level spell from the sorcerer spell list. You can cast that spell once without expending a spell slot or requiring material components, regaining the ability to cast that spell again after you’ve completed a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells. If a spell you gained from this feature, or from a Draconic Power, requires an action to cast, you can cast it with a bonus action instead.

entries.name: Drake Style
entries: Not all dragon warriors are descendants of true dragons, sometimes they are kin of lesser dragons such as drakes. As such, you are more versed in fighting with a pack of allies rather than relying on your own strength. You can use the {@action help} action as a bonus action. In addition, you have advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of your allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Dragon Style
entries: True dragons are most notable for their ability to breathe raw, magical energies. You learn to breathe a small portion of this energy and imbue your attacks with it. As a bonus action you can imbue your strikes with draconic energy. The next time you hit with a weapon or unarmed strike, you can add an additional 1d4 damage associated with your draconic origin. The extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, becoming a d6 at 7th level, a d8 at 11th level, and a d10 at 15th level.

entries.name: Serpentine Style
entries: You’re nimble and flexible, allowing you to quickly strike and limit an enemy’s movements. When you hit with a melee attack, you can immediately use a bonus action to attempt a {@action grapple} on that target. When you make a {@action grapple} in this way, you can make a Dexterity (Acrobatics) check instead of a Strength (Athletics) check to {@action grapple} the creature. You otherwise follow the {@action grapple} rules as normal. (See page 195 of the Player’s Handbook for more information about the Grapple action.)

entries.name: Wyvern Style
entries: Being descended from one of the lesser dragons, the wyvern, your strikes are more wildly and less calculated but equally more powerful and deadly. As a bonus action, you can make your next melee attack a wild attack, extending the reach of your attack by 5 feet and gaining a bonus 1d4 to the damage of your attack. This bonus increases as you gain levels in this class, becoming 1d6 at 5th level, 1d8 at 11th level, and 1d10 at 17th level.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Draconic Power
entries: {@i 7th-level Mystic feature}

As part of your training, you’ve chosen to become more familiar with your draconic heritage. You may choose two additional Draconic Powers which don’t count against your total number of Draconic Powers.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Style Improvement
entries: {@i 7th-level Mystic feature}
The Draconic Style you chose gains the following improvement depending on the style you chose:

entries.name: Arcane
entries: You learn two additional spells from the sorcerer spell list. The chosen spells can be any of 2nd or 3rd levels. You can cast either of these spells once without expending a spell slot or requiring material components, regaining the ability to cast that spell again after you’ve completed a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells. If a spell you gained from this feature requires an action to cast, you can cast it with a bonus action instead.

entries.name: Drake
entries: When a creature within 5 feet of you would be hit by an attack, you can use your reaction to direct some of the impact of that attack to you. You can halve the damage that creature would have taken and you take that damage instead.

entries.name: Dragon
entries: When you use your bonus action to imbue your attacks with draconic energy, the benefit is given to the next two attacks that hit with weapons or unarmed strikes, instead of just the next one.

entries.name: Serpentine
entries: A creature you {@action grapple} also becomes {@condition restrained} as you enhance your {@action grapple} with a magical power within you. This power can be represented by a spiritual serpent-like dragon coiling around them, but ultimately the flavor of this ability is up to you.

entries.name: Wyvern
entries: When you make a wild attack, you can choose to make that attack at advantage. If you do so, the next attack roll made against you before the start of your next turn has advantage.

subclassFeature.name: Mystical Strikes
entries: {@i 10th-level Mystic feature}

Your soul is permanently mixed with your draconic heritage, allowing you to grasp the ancient power of your ancestors in desperate moments. Once per round when you hit with a weapon attack or an unarmed strike, you can choose to convert all of the damage from that attack to force as you release outward the power of your ancestral dragon.
When you do so, you add a bonus 1d8 force damage to the damage of that attack. This bonus becomes 1d10 at 20th level.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Style Advancement
entries: {@i 14th-level Mystic feature}
Depending on the Draconic Style you chose, you gain one of the following benefits:

entries.name: Arcane
entries: You learn two additional spells from the sorcerer spell list. The chosen spells can be any of 3rd or 4th levels. You can cast either of these spells once without expending a spell slot or requiring material components, regaining the ability to cast that spell again after you’ve completed a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells. If a spell you gained from this feature requires an action to cast, you can cast it with a bonus action instead.

entries.name: Drake
entries: When you use the help action, both you and the target of your help action gain temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Dragon
entries: Your movement speed increases by 10 feet and you gain a climb or swim speed (you choose when you gain this feature) equal to your walking speed.

entries.name: Serpentine
entries: You can grapple a creature of any size category, regardless of the size difference between you and the target of your {@action grapple}.

entries.name: Wyvern
entries: When you hit with your wild attack, the next attack it makes before the start of your next turn has disadvantage.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Mystical Strikes
entries: {@i 17th-level Mystic feature}
Your weapon attacks and unarmed strikes deal an additional 1d8 force damage on hit. This bonus becomes 1d10 at 20th level.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Style Mastery
entries: {@i 20th-level Mystic feature}
Depending on the Draconic Style you chose, you gain one of the following benefits:

entries.name: Arcane
entries: When you take the attack action, you can replace one of your attacks with a spell you gained from one of your Mystic features or Draconic Powers, provided you have a use of the chosen spell. You can only do so once per round.

entries.name: Drake
entries: When you or an ally within 5 feet of you hits with an attack, you or that ally can add a bonus to the damage equal to your Charisma modifier.

entries.name: Dragon
entries: When you use your bonus action to imbue your attacks with draconic energy, you can apply the benefits for 1 minute, having no other restriction on how many times you can apply the additional damage for that duration.

entries.name: Serpentine
entries: Creatures who are {@condition grappled} by you deal half damage with attacks made with weapons or unarmed strikes.

entries.name: Wyvern
entries: You can make two wild attacks as part of your attack action instead of one when you use your bonus action to do so. When you do, the next two attacks made against you before the start of your next turn have advantage.

subclassFeature.name: Extraplanar Summoner
entries: {@i 1st-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

Born with a connection to planar magic, sorcerers of this origin are capable of summoning creatures of varying origins. Aberrations, celestials, constructs, fey, fiends, monstrosities, and even undead creatures can be conjured by these odd spellcasters. Your innate magic comes from the other planes, such as the feywild, shadowfell, the outer planes such as the abyss, nine hells, or even mount celestia.

Extraplanar summoners are extremely handy to have due to the powerful allies they can conjure, however they are tied directly to you, so keeping yourself alive is just as important as keeping your ally healthy.

subclassFeature.name: Summoner Magic
entries: Your magic comes from the planes outside the material one, granting you powerful conjuration magic. You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Extraplanar Summoner Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be a {@filter conjuration spell from the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock;wizard|school=C|level=1;2;3;4;5}.

subclassFeature.name: Extraplanar Ally
entries: {@i 1st-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

As an action, you bind another creature’s soul from another plane to your whim and place it within a body you magically conjure. Choose one of the following creature types: aberration, celestial, construct, elemental, fey, fiend, monstrosity, or undead. Depending on the creature type you chose, use the corresponding Extraplanar Ally stat block. The creature obeys your commands and is friendly to you and your allies. It shares your initiative but moves and takes actions either right before or after your turn. If you are reduced to 0 hit points and are knocked unconscious, your connection to the planar ally ends and it returns to the plane from once it came. You can use an action and spend a spell slot of any level to summon it again, but it returns with the hit points and conditions it had prior to returning to its plane.

In addition to summoning the creature, you gain a magical benefit depending on the creature type you chose. You gain one of the following benefits until the Extraplanar Ally is destroyed or returns to its home plane:

entries.name: Aberration
entries: You gain the ability to speak telepathically to creatures you can see within 60 ft of you. In addition, you can reach into the minds of other creatures and cripple them. You can cast the {@spell Vicious Mockery} cantrip as if it were a sorcerer spell for you.

entries.name: Celestial
entries: You gain resistance to radiant damage and can spend your bonus action to heal a creature within 30 ft of you a number of hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Construct
entries: You gain resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage and as a bonus action you can change the damage type of your next spell to force damage until the end of your next turn. You concentrate on this effect as if you were concentrating on a spell.

entries.name: Elemental
entries: Choose fire, water, earth, or air. In the Extraplanar Ally (Elemental) statblock you use the features corresponding to the chosen type. You gain resistance to poison damage and have advantage on saving throws against being poisoned.

entries.name: Fey
entries: You gain resistance to psychic damage and you have advantage on saving throws against being charmed.

entries.name: Fiend
entries: You gain resistance to fire damage you can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, to a distance of 60 feet.

entries.name: Monstrosity
entries: You gain a natural weapon in the form of claws or fangs. These natural weapons use your spellcasting ability modifier instead of strength or dexterity for its attack and damage rolls and deal 1d6 slashing or piercing damage (your choice). In addition your armor class increases by half your proficiency bonus (rounded up).

entries.name: Undead
entries: You gain resistance to necrotic damage and whenever you deal damage with a spell you can add an additional amount of necrotic damage to the spell equal to your proficiency bonus.

Your Extraplanar Ally is destroyed when it is reduced to 0 hit points or if it is successfully banished via the Banishment spell, or other similar effect. When it is destroyed, its soul returns to its home plane. It retains no memories from when it was traveling with you while on its home plane and when it is summoned again it regains the lost memories. After your Extraplanar Ally is destroyed, you cannot summon it again until you finish a long rest.

You cannot have more than one Extraplanar Ally at any given time. You can dismiss your Extraplanar Ally as an action, or freely during a short or long rest. Once you dismiss your Extraplanar Ally, you cannot summon a new one until you have finished a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Summoner Savant
entries: {@i 6th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

When you cast a conjuration spell of 1st level or higher, you can choose to ignore the material cost of the spell. When you do so, you must use an arcane focus, but it does not get consumed by the spell.
