You use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Synergist
entries: {@i 6th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

Your Extraplanar Ally adds your proficiency bonus to its damage rolls for its weapon attacks. Your Extraplanar’s attacks are considered magical for the purposes of overcoming non-magical resistances. In addition, the benefit you gain from your Extraplanar Ally feature gets improved based on the creature type, the following changes (or additions) are made to said benefit:

entries.name: Aberration
entries: You add an additional amount of psychic damage to {@spell Vicious Mockery|PHB} equal to your proficiency bonus and your telepathy’s range increases to 120 ft.

entries.name: Celestial
entries: When you heal a creature using the benefit you gain from your Extraplanar Ally feature, you can spend sorcery points up to your proficiency bonus to add 1d4 healing per sorcery point spent.

entries.name: Construct
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being paralyzed.

entries.name: Elemental
entries: You have immunity to poison damage instead of resistance.

entries.name: Fey
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

entries.name: Fiend
entries: You can see normally in darkness, magical or nonmagical, to a range of 120 ft instead of 60ft.

entries.name: Monstrosity
entries: Your speed increases by 15 ft and you gain an amount of temporary hit points equal to twice your proficiency bonus when you gain this feature, finish a long rest, or summon your Extraplanar Ally as a monstrosity.

entries.name: Undead
entries: When you hit a creature with a spell, you can spend 2 sorcery points to make that creature unable to gain the benefits of healing until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Combative Ally
entries: {@i 14th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}
Your Extraplanar Ally gets multiattack, allowing it to make up to two attacks instead of one when it takes the attack action.

In addition, as a bonus action on your turn you can spend a sorcery point to give a number of temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus to your Extraplanar Ally if it is within 60 ft of you.

subclassFeature.name: Extraplanar Master
entries: {@i 18th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

You can summon an Extraplanar Ally two times instead of once before you have to finish a long rest if it is destroyed or dismissed, but you can still only have one summoned Extraplanar Ally at any given time.

In addition when you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, your Extraplanar Ally receives an amount of healing equal to the spell's level plus your proficiency bonus. This healing bypasses its Constructed Body feature.
Your Extraplanar Ally, and creatures you summon using a Conjuration spell of 1st level or higher gain an amount of temporary hit points when they are summoned equal to your sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Remedies
entries: Nature provides natural forms of remedies for poisons, disease, illness, and wounds. Druids a part of this circle are particularly skilled in taking these natural remedies and magically enhancing them, dedicating their lives to preserving the lives of their circle and the lives of the creatures of their terrain.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Many druids form a connection to nature, but few to this level. Your connection to the natural world grants you access to some spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Circle of Remedies Spells table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

entries.caption: Circle of Remedies Spells
rows: {@spell speak with plants}, {@spell mass healing word}

subclassFeature.name: Natural Herbalist
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your proficiency bonus is doubled when you make an ability check using a herbalism kit. In addition, you gain proficiency in Nature and Survival and your proficiency bonus is doubled when making an ability check using those skills.
In addition, you are an expert at brewing potions of healing. The cost and time required for you to craft potions of healing is halved.

subclassFeature.name: Remedies of The Wild
entries: Also at 2nd level, by performing a 10 minute ritual you can magically create special herbs that can be used as medical remedies. You create a number of these remedies equal to your proficiency bonus, choosing from the following remedies for each one:

entries.name: Remedy of Wound Closure
entries: A creature may use a bonus action to quickly chew on this remedy, igniting regenerative properties. They magically regain 1d6 plus your Wisdom modifier hit points and any scars, magical or non-magical, are removed. This healing has no effect on undead or constructs and has no effects on unconscious creatures.

entries.name: Remedy of Curing
entries: A creature may use a bonus action to consume this remedy, removing any poisons or diseases afflicting them.

entries.name: Remedy of Revitalization
entries: A creature may use an action to break this remedy and release a magical vapor which rejuvenates an {@condition unconscious} creature. An {@condition unconscious} creature that is not at 0 hit points becomes awake and conscious again, unless they are cursed to be {@condition unconscious}. A creature at 0 hit points and is {@condition unconscious} regains 1 hit point and regains consciousness, instantly coming to their feet with a burst of energy.
A creature may also use an action to apply these remedies to another creature.

Once you create these magical remedies, they last for 24 hours until they lose their potency and you cannot create them again until you finish a short or long rest. The first time you use this feature after each long rest, you can create these magical remedies without expending a spell slot. All other times you expend a spell slot of 1st-level or higher.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Remedies
entries: At 6th level, the list of remedies you can create expands as your knowledge of remedies increases:

entries.name: Remedy of Restoration
entries: A creature can use an action to apply this remedy to themselves or another creature, allowing them to remove one condition listed in the {@spell lesser restoration} spell.

entries.name: Remedy of Heightened Senses
entries: A creature can use a bonus action to apply this remedy on their eyes and ears. The creature has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks and gains the benefits of the {@spell see invisibility} spell for 1 hour. After the hour has passed, the creature becomes blinded and deafened for 1 minute as pain swells up in their eyes and ears suffering the drawback of the remedy.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Guardian
entries: Also at 6th level, while you are transformed by Wild Shape, you can use a bonus action to expend one spell slot to have yourself, or a creature you can see within 30 feet of you regain 1d6 hit points per level of the spell slot expended. Regardless of how many dice you roll, you add your Wisdom modifier to the total amount of hit points restored.

In addition, as a bonus action while in your Wild Shape form or your normal form, you can gain a restorative aura that heals your allies that extends out to a 10-foot radius which lasts for 1 minute. Each creature (other than yourself) that starts its turn in the aura, or enters it for the first time on its turn, regains a number of hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.
A creature can recover hit points from this aura a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining the ability to heal from it again when they finish a long rest.
Once you create this aura, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest unless you expend a 3rd-level or higher spell slot to regain a use of the aura.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Remedies
entries: At 10th level, the list of remedies you can create expands as your knowledge of remedies increases:

entries.name: Remedy of Adrenaline
entries: A creature can use a bonus action to inhale this remedy, granting them a boost in motor functions. They gain the benefits of the {@spell haste} spell for a number of rounds equal to your proficiency bonus. They suffer from the lethargy the haste spell gives after the benefits ends.

entries.name: Remedy of Stone Melting
entries: A creature can use an action to apply this remedy onto a {@condition petrified} creature. At the end of the {@condition petrified} creature’s next turn, they are no longer {@condition petrified}.

subclassFeature.name: Champion of Nature
entries: At 14th level, you’ve achieved the peak of your magical abilities. There is no longer a limit to how many times a creature can heal from your aura created by your Nature’s Guardian feature and the aura becomes a 20-foot radius. In addition, you also regain hit points at the start of your turns while your aura is active.

Also, when you restore hit points to a creature using a spell of 1st-level or higher, or when they would restore hit points from one of your remedies, they regain an additional amount of hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: College of Minstrel
entries: The College of Minstrel cannot be found on any map, nor is it defined to one location. No one place is defined as home to these bards, rather, they consider those they travel with their true home. The world is their home, and the people in it are mere extensions of their family. These bards protect their family as they would themselves and focus on healing. These bards also have a particular liking to poetry and songs, as it spreads joy to those who listen.

subclassFeature.name: Traveler's Song
entries: At 3rd level, while travelling or spending downtime you can play a song that keeps your allies focused and determined on their tasks.

Provided your allies can see or hear you during the task, they have advantage on any ability checks associated with the task. When you use this feature, you are assumed to be spending your own ability to partake in downtime activities or other tasks during travel, however you may still partake in certain tasks, such as performing at a tavern if the allies you are aiding are in said tavern, with approval by your DM.
In addition, one of those creatures may add a bonus to one of their rolls equal to one roll of your bardic inspiration die.

As an example, a Ranger who goes hunting for resources during downtime can have advantage on their Wisdom (Survival) ability check in addition to any other ability checks associated with hunting. Or, if you are traveling at a slow pace to stealth during your travel for safety, you and your allies can have advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks, provided they can see you. A wizard who is trying to sell a magic item in a tavern may still allow you to perform entertainment for the tavern and grant the benefits to the wizard.

subclassFeature.name: Minstrel's Melody
entries: Also at 3rd level, when a 1st level or higher spell you cast would restore a creature’s hit points, they can regain an additional amount of hit points equal to one roll of your bardic inspiration die. A creature that receives this bonus gains a bonus to their next attack roll, ability check, or saving throw they make until the start of your next turn equal to the number rolled on the inspiration die.

subclassFeature.name: Shelter of The Travelers
entries: Starting at 6th level, you learn the {@spell Leomund's tiny hut} spell, which counts as a bard spell for you but doesn’t count against your total number of known spells, and you can cast it once without expending a spell slot or requiring material components. When you cast the spell using this feature, the dome created covers a 20-foot radius instead, allowing more than 9 medium or smaller creatures to fit inside the radius, and you can enter and exit the hut as you please without ending the spell.

The hut itself, and creatures inside of the hut, are {@condition invisible} for the duration of the spell. As an action, you can allow the hut and the creatures inside of the hut to be seen, or you can use another action to hide the hut and the creatures inside.
You regain the ability to cast the spell in this way again when you finish a long rest, or if you expend a spell slot of 3rd level or higher to regain the ability to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Minstrel's Duet
entries: At 14th level, when you restore hit points to another creature using a spell of 1st-level or higher, you regain hit points equal to two rolls of your bardic inspiration die.

subclassFeature.name: Minstrel's Inspiration
entries: Also at 14th level, a creature with one of your bardic inspiration regains a number of hit points at the start of each of their turns equal to one roll of your bardic inspiration die. They also regain hit points when they use their bardic inspiration equal to the number rolled on the inspiration die.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Charity
entries: The oath of charity binds a paladin to the greatest ideals of sacrifice, good will, giving to those in need, and protecting those who need aid. These are warriors who focus their efforts on healing just as much as they do fighting. They hold themselves to never give in to selfish desires, to offer a healing hand to the injured, and to give to those who will not just take.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Charity
entries: {@i Though the exact words and strictures of the Oath of Charity vary, paladins of this oath share these tenets.}

entries.name: Charity
entries: Give to the poor, especially when you have plenty to make do with.

entries.name: Sacrifice
entries: Always be willing to pay the ultimate price for the benefit of others.

entries.name: Tempered
entries: Stay true to your emotions, but never let them consume you.

entries.name: Heal and Protect
entries: Heal the weakened innocents, and ensure they are not harmed again.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed.

entries.caption: Oath of Charity Spells
rows: {@spell create food and water}, {@spell life transference|XGE}

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Mend the Wounded
entries: You can hasten your efforts to heal a wounded creature using your channel divinity. For the next minute, you can use your Lay on Hands feature as a bonus action rather than an action. Also for the duration, when you restore hit points to a creature using a spell of 1st level or higher, you can add a bonus to the roll equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Protect the Weak
entries: You can use your channel divinity to protect an ally from the jaws of defeat. When a creature you can see within 60 feet of you would be reduced to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to have them be reduced to 1 hit point instead.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Regeneration
entries: Starting at 7th level, you can keep others alive when they are struggling through the midst of battle. When a creature (other than yourself) with less than half of their maximum hit points starts their turn within 10 feet of you, they regain a number of hit points equal to your Charisma modifier.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Shield the Wounded
entries: At 15th level, you can use a bonus action to choose a creature you can see within 60 feet of you that doesn’t have all of their hit points. Until the start of your next turn, creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls against the chosen creature.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Giver of Life
entries: At 20th level you can channel your divine power to invoke powerful healing abilities. As a bonus action, you gain the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: When you would normally roll one or more dice to restore hit points with a spell, you instead use the highest number possible for each die.
When you cast a spell that restores hit points using a 1st-level spell slot or higher, the spell is treated as if it were one level higher than the expended slot.
If a creature within 30 feet of you fails a saving throw, you can spend your reaction and a 1st-level or higher spell slot to have them re-roll. They must use the new result.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest, unless you expend a 5th-level spell slot to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Knight
entries: Choosing a darker path, you've stripped your morality and humanity to enhance your martial prowess. Harnessing blood magic and enhancing your fighting style further with these dark arts.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in one of the following skills of your choice: Arcana, Insight, Medicine, or Religion.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomancy
entries: {@i 3rd-level Blood Knight feature}

Studying occult-based magic, you’ve learned the very nature of blood magic and can use it yourself to a limited degree. Your blood magic will be represented by hemomancy dice. These dice are d4s and you have a number of hemomancy dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus.

You use these dice to fuel your blood magic abilities, and you regain all of your hemomancy dice after a long rest. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than you can have at your current level in this way. If a hemomancy feature requires a creature to make a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.

When you use a Hemomancy die, regardless if it is spent or not, you roll the die and take damage equal to what you roll. Your hemomancy dice grows stronger with you as you gain levels in this class, becoming a d6 at 7th level, a d8 at 10th level, a d10 at 15th level, and a d12 at 18th level.
You can use your hemomancy dice in the following ways:

entries.name: Blood-Boosted Accuracy
entries: Whenever you would miss with a weapon attack, you can use a hemomancy die and add a bonus to the roll equal to what you rolled, potentially turning the attack into a hit. If it hits, you deal a number of necrotic damage equal to what you rolled to that creature. You spend the hemomancy die only if the attack hits.

entries.name: Blood Bursting Strike
entries: Whenever you deal damage with a weapon, you can expend a hemomancy die and roll it, adding a number of necrotic damage equal to the number rolled and then that creature makes a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature has disadvantage on attack rolls until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Forge
entries: {@i 3rd-level Blood Knight feature}

You have the innate ability to morph your blood into volatile weapons and ammunition. As a bonus action, you can create either a blood weapon or blood ammunition. You can use this feature once per long rest, or you can spend a hemomancy die to use it again. The created weapon or pieces of ammunition lasts for 1 hour, or a number of hours equal to the damage you took from the hemomancy die.

entries.name: Blood Weapon
entries: You conjure a red glass-like magical melee weapon with the finesse and thrown properties. When you throw it, it has a range of 60 feet and no long range. When thrown, it magically reappears in your hand after it hits or misses a target. It deals necrotic damage on hit equal to your hemomancy die.

entries.name: Blood Ammunition
entries: You conjure 10 pieces of red glass-like ammunition. It can take any form of ammunition, so long as it can be used by a ranged weapon. Using these pieces of ammunition changes the damage type of your ranged weapon to necrotic and you can choose to replace the damage die with your hemomancy die.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Bath
entries: {@i 7th-level Blood Knight feature}

You can push your body to its absolute limit to unleash a dark power from within using a combination of the power of your will and your rage. You can spend a hemomancy die to enter a blood bath. As a bonus action, you magically gain the following benefits, which last for 1 minute:

items: Whenever you deal damage using a weapon, you can deal an additional amount of damage equal to your proficiency bonus. The damage dealt is of the weapon’s damage type.
You can forgo one of your extra attacks to gain advantage on all of your weapon attacks for the rest of this turn.
Whenever you take damage, except from your hemomancy dice, once per round you can reduce that damage by half using your reaction.
As a bonus action, and part of the bonus action used to enter your blood bath, you can make one weapon attack using a blood weapon.

entries: During your Blood Bath, each time you hit with a weapon attack you lose 1 hit point. Your blood bath ends early if you are reduced to 0 hit points, incapacitated, or die. You can use your blood bath once, regaining the ability to use it again when you complete a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Reserves
entries: {@i 10th-level Blood Knight feature}

Whenever you use your Second Wind feature while your Blood Bath is active, you can add an additional amount of healing equal to your hemomancy die as you draw upon even greater reserves of power from your blood magic. This expends a Hemomancy Die but does not deal damage to yourself for using it.

In addition, as a bonus action you can deal damage to yourself equal to your hemomancy die and regain a spent hemomancy die. You can do so once, regaining the ability to do so when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomatic Bulwark
entries: {@i 15th-level Blood Knight feature}
The following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Blood Barrier
entries: As a reaction whenever you would be hit by an attack, you can spend a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to your AC until the start of your next turn, potentially turning the attack into a miss.

entries.name: Blood-Boosted Ability
entries: Whenever you make an ability check or saving throw that uses Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution, you may use a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to the d20, provided you are not incapacitated. You spend the hemomancy die only if the check or save was successful.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomatic Mastery
entries: {@i 18th-level Blood Knight feature}
You regain all of your spent Hemomancy Dice whenever you finish a short or long rest. In addition, the following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Blood Curse
entries: As an action, you can spend a hemomancy die to magically curse a creature within 60 feet of you that you can see. That creature becomes overwhelmed and cursed by your blood magic for 1 minute. That creature becomes vulnerable to necrotic damage and gains no benefits from having resistance to necrotic damage. A creature makes a Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. A creature is immune to this effect if it is a plant, undead, or construct, or if it is immune to necrotic damage. You can only have one creature affected by your blood curse at a time. A remove curse can also remove these effects.

entries.name: Bloody End
entries: When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points, as a reaction you can absorb part of its life force into your own body to fuel your vitality. You can spend a hemomancy die and roll it, gaining a number of temporary hit points equal to what you rolled plus your Constitution modifier. You do not take damage when you spend a hemomancy die in this way.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Sorcery
entries: Blood magic is often used by worshipers of evil gods, demons, or arch devils. Rarely though, some are born to be a blood mage through demonic or devilish origins. Tieflings are strong candidates for becoming blood mages, but anyone of any racial origin has the potential for it. A blood mage is often seen as a sign of some powerful demon or devil seeping into the material plane and killing a blood mage is often associated with keeping said demon or devil in their respective planes. As such, natural born blood mages are hunted and killed.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Magic
entries: {@i 1st-level Sanguine feature}

Your magic comes from the demonic abyss, the infernal nine hells, or even from powerful witches. You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Blood Magic Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be an {@filter enchantment or necromancy spell from the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock;wizard|school=E,N|level=1;2;3;4;5} or a spell with the hemomancy subschool can be learned regardless of the class or school of magic.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomancy
entries: {@i 1st-level Sanguine feature}

Studying occult-based magic, you’ve learned the very nature of blood magic and can use it yourself to a limited degree. Your blood magic will be represented by hemomancy dice. These dice are d4s and you have a number of hemomancy dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus.

You use these dice to fuel your blood magic abilities, and you regain all of your hemomancy dice after a long rest. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than you can have at your current level in this way. If a hemomancy feature requires a creature to make a saving throw, the DC equals your Spell Save DC.

When you use a Hemomancy die, regardless if it is spent or not, you roll the die and take damage equal to what you roll. Your hemomancy dice grows stronger with you as you gain levels in this class, becoming a d6 at 5th level, a d8 at 9th level, a d10 at 13th level, and a d12 at 17th level.
You can use your hemomancy dice in the following ways:

entries.name: Blood-Homing Spell
entries: When you make a spell attack you can use a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to the attack roll. If it hits, you deal an additional amount of necrotic damage equal to the number rolled. You spend the hemomancy die only if you hit.

entries.name: Blood-Bursting Magic
entries: When you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you can spend a hemomancy die to release outward a burst of necromantic energy. Each creature of your choice within 10 feet of you takes necrotic damage equal to the number rolled on the hemomancy die plus your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Bolstering Magic
entries: {@i 6th-level Sanguine feature}

Your innate blood magic allows you to manipulate your spells more efficiently. When you use a metamagic option that would ordinarily spend sorcery points, you can choose to spend hemomancy dice for every sorcery point that would have been used. You still roll the hemomancy dice and take damage equal to what you roll as normal.

Also, you can use a bonus action to spend a sorcery point to regain a spent hemomancy die. You can use this bonus action a number times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Resistance
entries: {@i 6th-level Sanguine feature}
You have resistance to poison and necrotic damage and you have advantage on saving throws made to resist being poisoned or diseased.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Magic
entries: {@i 14th-level Sanguine feature}

During short moments of respite you can regain some of your lost sorcerous power. When you finish a short rest, you can spend a hit die to regain sorcery points equal to the number rolled. You can only spend a hit die in this way once, regaining the ability to do so again when you complete a long rest.
In addition, you the following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Sanguine Spell
entries: Your blood magic can be used to empower your magic further. When you make an ability check for a spell you cast, you can roll a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to the d20. You spend the hemomancy die only if the check is successful.

entries.name: Blood Concentrate
entries: When your body fails your magic, you can draw on power to endure further. When you would drop concentration on a spell, you can spend a hemomancy die to maintain that concentration. The damage you take from this ability does not break concentration on said spell.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Transformation
entries: {@i 18th-level Sanguine feature}
Your mastery over blood magic has further changed your body permanently, granting you immunity to necrotic damage and immunity to being diseased.

In addition, you can undergo a more powerful transformation which furthers your mastery over said magic. You learn the spell {@spell Guise of the Blood Witch|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting} and it counts as a sorcerer spell for you but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. You can cast the spell without requiring material components and you can cast it without expending a spell slot by spending hemomancy dice instead. You can cast the spell in this way once, regaining the ability to do so again when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: School of Blood Magic
entries: Shrouded by curiosity and insidious methods, you have sacrificed a portion of your mortality to gain greater arcane power. You’ll do anything to get an edge over your opponents, even at the cost of your own strength.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: {@i 2nd-level Blood Magic feature}
You gain proficiency in either intimidation or religion.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomancy
entries: {@i 2nd-level Blood Magic feature}

Studying occult-based magic, you’ve learned the very nature of blood magic and can use it yourself to a limited degree. Your blood magic will be represented by hemomancy dice. These dice are d4s and you have a number of hemomancy dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus.

You use these dice to fuel your blood magic abilities, and you regain all of your hemomancy dice after a long rest. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than you can have at your current level in this way. If a hemomancy feature requires a creature to make a saving throw, the DC equals your Spell Save DC.

When you use a Hemomancy die, regardless if it is spent or not, you roll the die and take damage equal to what you roll. Your hemomancy dice grows stronger with you as you gain levels in this class, becoming a d6 at 6th level, a d8 at 9th level, a d10 at 14th level, and a d12 at 17th level.
You can use your hemomancy dice in the following ways:

entries.name: Blood Drenched Mind
entries: When you make an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw that uses intelligence, you can use a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to the check. You spend the hemomancy die only if the check is successful.

entries.name: Blood Soaked Spell
entries: When you cast a spell of 1st level or higher that deals damage, you can spend a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to one of the damage rolls of the spell.

entries.name: Blood Focus
entries: As a bonus action, you can use a hemomancy die to empower an arcane focus or a component pouch for 1 hour. When you do, you can treat that arcane focus for the component cost of spells with costly components, up to a maximum component cost of 50 gp x the number rolled on the hemomancy die. If you use it for a spell that consumes the material component, the empowerment ends early. The first time you use this ability before you finish a long rest you do not spend the hemomancy die, every time after the first until you complete a long rest you spend it.

subclassFeature.name: Dark Devotion
entries: {@i 6th-level Blood Magic feature}
Your devotion to the dark arts of blood magic gives you a will stronger than most. You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed or frightened.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Savant
entries: {@i 6th-level Blood Magic feature}
As a bonus action you can spend a spell slot of any level to regain a number of spent hemomancy dice equal to the slot’s level. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than the maximum you can have.

subclassFeature.name: Sigils of the Blood Arcane
entries: {@i 10th-level Blood Magic feature}

You’ve discovered an arcane sigil that allows you to learn new blood magic spells. Choose two spells from the cleric, warlock, or wizard classes. A spell you choose must be of a level you can cast, as shown on the Wizard table, or a cantrip. Each spell is represented by an arcane sigil, which appears in your spell book. These spells are always prepared and count as wizard spells for you. You choose one additional spell at 14th level, and one more at 17th level.
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of those spells with another one from the same listed spell lists.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Magic Mastery
entries: {@i 14th-level Blood Magic feature}

You can cast the spells chosen from your Sigils of the Blood Arcane feature with expending a spell slot by spending a number a hemomancy dice equal to the spell’s level. When you cast one of these spells in this way, you must cast it at its lowest level and you cannot cast that spell in this way again until you finish a long rest.
In addition, the following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Bleeding Spell
entries: Whenever you deal damage with a spell, you can use a hemomancy die (no action required) and force that creature to make a constitution saving throw. On a failed save, for a number of rounds equal to the number rolled on the hemomancy die they take damage at the start of each of their turns equal to one roll of your hemomancy die. Rolling the hemomancy die in that way does not deal damage to yourself. The type of damage they take is the damage type of the spell. On a successful save, they do not take damage at the start of their turns. You spend the hemomancy die only if they failed their save.

entries.name: Blood Invocation
entries: When you begin casting a spell, you can replace one or more of the components required for the spell by spending a hemomancy die for each component replaced. If you replace a material component for the spell, the material must not require to be consumed and must have a maximum cost of 500 gp, otherwise it cannot be replaced with a hemomancy die.

subclassFeature.name: Bleeding Knife
entries: Trained in the most deadly forms of magic, blood magic. Though powerful, it is a double edged sword as you inflict yourself a great sacrifice to perform such deadly arts. Rogues of this roguish archetype are trained in the more graceful abilities of blood magic, allowing them to improve on their already insane ability of rapid takedowns.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomancy
entries: {@i 3rd-level Bleeding Knife feature}

Studying occult-based magic, you’ve learned the very nature of blood magic and can use it yourself to a limited degree. Your blood magic will be represented by hemomancy dice. These dice are d4s and you have a number of hemomancy dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus.

You use these dice to fuel your blood magic abilities, and you regain all of your hemomancy dice after a long rest. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than you can have at your current level in this way. If a hemomancy feature requires a creature to make a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier.

When you use a Hemomancy die, regardless if it is spent or not, you roll the die and take damage equal to what you roll. Your hemomancy dice grows stronger with you as you gain levels in this class, becoming a d6 at 7th level, a d8 at 10th level, a d10 at 15th level, and a d12 at 18th level.
You can use your hemomancy dice in the following ways:

entries.name: Bleeding Edge
entries: You coat your weapons in your own blood, enhancing its deadly capabilities. When you hit a creature with a finesse or ranged weapon and gain the benefits of your sneak attack feature, you use a hemomancy die and force that creature to make a constitution saving throw. On a failed save, roll your hemomancy die and for that many rounds that creature is poisoned. You spend the hemomancy die only if the creature fails the saving throw.

entries.name: Blood-Boosted Adrenaline
entries: When you take the dash action, you can spend and roll a hemomancy die to move an additional number of feet equal to 5 times the number rolled as part of that dash action. Creatures you move within 5 feet of for the first time when you use this feature must make a Dexterity saving throw or take necrotic damage equal to what you rolled on a failed save, or half as much on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomatic Takedown
entries: {@i 3rd-level Bleeding Knife feature}
Using the power of your blood magic, you can magically change the damage type of your sneak attack to necrotic, this is known as a Hemomatic Takedown.

subclassFeature.name: Occultic Studies
entries: {@i 3rd-level Bleeding Knife feature}
You gain proficiency in your choice of Arcana or Religion. You also gain proficiency with a Poisoner’s Kit. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check made using this tool.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Talents
entries: {@i 9th-level Bleeding Knife feature}

Your occultic studies grants you various magical abilities, of which you can use at the cost of your own vitality. These blood talents can have a wide range of abilities, like casting spells for instance. You choose two Blood Talents to learn. If a Blood Talent casts a spell, you use intelligence for its spellcasting ability and you can only cast that spell at its lowest level unless otherwise specified. You learn an additional Blood Talent at 13th, 17th, and 20th levels.

entries.name: Blood Armor
entries: You can magically create a set of armor made up of your own blood infused with magic. You can cast {@spell Mage Armor} at will. When you do so, roll a hemomancy die and take damage equal to what you roll.

entries.name: Amorphous Transformation
entries: You can magically morph yourself into a blob of blood which can pass through narrow spaces. As an action by spending a hemomancy die, you can assume your amorphous transformation, which lasts for 1 minute. While in this form, you have the amorphous trait, which allows you to pass through spaces as narrow as 1 inch.

You still retain the ability to use your other features, abilities, and weapons in this form - however any damage you deal, whether it be from a spell or weapon, will instead deal necrotic damage. You can use this Blood Talent once, regaining the ability to do so again after a long rest, or you can spend a hit die during a short rest to regain the use of this Blood Talent.

entries.name: Blood Hex
entries: You can place a magical enchantment on a creature using your blood magic. You can cast the {@spell Hex} spell once without requiring material components, regaining the ability to do so again when you finish a long rest. Alternatively, you can spend a hemomancy die to regain the use of this ability.

entries.name: Blood Tendrils
entries: You can magically conjure tendrils made of your own blood and quickly lash out at your enemies. You can cast {@spell Arms of Hadar} by spending a hemomancy die.

entries.name: Slick Blood
entries: You can conjure a puddle of blood underneath your enemies’ feet, causing them to slip and tumble. You can cast {@spell Grease} by spending a hemomancy die without requiring material components.

entries.name: Prophetic Demise
entries: You can attempt to incite your will onto fate and control the destiny of your foes. You can cast {@spell bane} by spending a hemomancy die.

entries.name: Blood Infusion
entries: You can magically enchant your weapons using your blood magic. You can cast Magic Weapon by spending two hemomancy dice.

entries.name: Bleeding Ray of Pain
entries: You can summon an arcane power which can sunder your foes. You can cast {@spell Ray of Enfeeblement} by spending two hemancy dice.

entries.name: Masking Blood
entries: You can manifest a masking layer of blood to hide your true self. You can spend a hemomancy die to cast {@spell Disguise Self}.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomatic Expert
entries: {@i 13th-level Bleeding Knife feature}
The following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Vampiric Strikes
entries: When you use your Hemomatic Takedown, you can spend a Hemomancy die, roll it, and gain temporary hit points equal to the number rolled. Using the hemomancy die in this way does not deal damage to yourself.

entries.name: Occultic Influence
entries: Whenever you make an ability check or saving throw that uses Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma, you may use a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to the d20, provided you are not incapacitated. You spend the hemomancy die only if the check or save was successful.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Blood Talents
entries: {@i 13th-level Bleeding Knife feature}
The following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Animate Blood Servant
entries: Using your occultic magic, you can bring back the enemies you’ve slain. You can cast {@spell Animate Dead} without requiring material components by spending 3 hemomancy dice. You can use this talent once, regaining the ability to do so when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Spiteful Curse
entries: What sort of blood magic user comes without their own fair share of curses? You can spend 3 hemomancy dice to cast {@spell Bestow Curse}.

entries.name: Blood Rage
entries: You can fill the mind of a nearby creature with hate and rage to send them off into a blood lust. You can cast {@spell Enemies Abound|XGE} by spending 3 hemomancy dice.

entries.name: Vampiric Mist
entries: By borrowing a few tricks from the mighty vampires, you can turn into a magical mist to make a tricky escape. You can cast {@spell Gaseous Form} without requiring material components by spending 3 hemomancy dice.

entries.name: Vitality Transfer
entries: Sometimes, you just feel like donating your kidneys or something I guess. You can spend 3 hemomancy dice to cast {@spell Life Transference|XGE}. When you do so, the amount of damage you took from your hemomancy dice is added to the healing of the spell.

entries.name: Touch of the Wretched
entries: You can imbue yourself with the power of life sucking undead. You can spend 3 hemomancy dice to cast {@spell Vampiric Touch}. You can use this Blood Talent once, regaining the ability to do so when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Veil of the Occult
entries: Sometimes you need to stay hidden, at all costs, including by pesky divination magic. You can spend 4 hemomancy dice to cast {@spell Nondetection} without requiring material components. You can use this Blood Talent once, regaining the ability to do so when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Assassin
entries: {@i 17th-level Bleeding Knife feature}
You’ve mastered the art of hemomancy and have fully incorporated it into your everyday talents. You regain half of your spent hemomancy dice whenever you finish a short rest.
Using your mastery over Hemomancy, whenever you deal damage using your Hemomatic Takedown you can impose a deadly strike to a creature whose CR is equal to or lower than your own.

The affected creature makes a Constitution saving throw against your Hemomancy Save DC. On a failed save, the creature takes necrotic damage equal to your Rogue level and the next Hemomatic Takedown deals and is incapacitated until the end of your next turn. On a success, the creature takes necrotic damage equal to half your rogue level and is not incapacitated.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: The Blood Witch
entries: Said to be the first to unlock this ancient form of fiendish magic, The Blood Witch is a very mysterious entity with a sort of mastery over blood magic. Where she acquired it from exactly is still unknown, as are many things about her. Some that have met her have claimed her to be a deity, while others refer to her as a false god with an exaggerated ego. She is revered by cultists as the first and one true master of the blood arts, while many see her as a stepping stone into their own wicked ascension.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: {@i 1st-level The Blood Witch feature}
The Blood Witch lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomancy
entries: {@i 1st-level The Blood Witch feature}

Studying occult-based magic, you’ve learned the very nature of blood magic and can use it yourself to a limited degree. Your blood magic will be represented by hemomancy dice. These dice are d4s and you have a number of hemomancy dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus.

You use these dice to fuel your blood magic abilities, and you regain all of your hemomancy dice after a long rest. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than you can have at your current level in this way. If a hemomancy feature requires a creature to make a saving throw, the DC equals your Spell Save DC.

When you use a Hemomancy die, regardless if it is spent or not, you roll the die and take damage equal to what you roll. Your hemomancy dice grows stronger with you as you gain levels in this class, becoming a d6 at 5th level, a d8 at 9th level, a d10 at 13th level, and a d12 at 17th level.
You can use your hemomancy dice in the following ways:

entries.name: Hex of the Witch
entries: As a bonus action, you can spend a hemomancy die to magically curse a creature you can see within 60 feet of you. When you do, that creature cannot regain hit points for a number of rounds equal to the number rolled. At the start of each of the affected creature’s turns, it takes necrotic damage equal to your hemomancy die. You concentrate on this hex as if you were concentrating on a spell.

entries.name: Blood Transmutation
entries: When you cast a cantrip that deals damage, you can use a hemomancy die to convert the damage type of the cantrip into necrotic damage until the end of the current turn and one damage roll receives an additional amount of necrotic damage equal to the number rolled on the hemomancy die. The first time you use this ability after each long rest, you don't expend the hemomancy die. All other times you use the ability, you expend the die.

subclassFeature.name: Eyes of The Blood Witch
entries: {@i 1st-level The Blood Witch feature}

The Blood Witch was said to have a special sense that allowed her to find hidden paths and secret doors. As an action, you can inherit this magical sense for 1 minute. While you have this magical sight, you can potentially see through illusions and {@condition invisible} creatures and objects as if they weren’t invisible.

This magical sight is limited however, as it is only a portion of The Blood Witch’s true sight. In order to see an {@condition invisible} creature or object, you must pass a Wisdom (Perception) check in order to properly see it. If the creature was hidden, then the DC is the Dexterity (Stealth) check it made, or if it wasn’t hidden the DC is 5 + the CR of the creature. If the object is {@condition invisible}, the DC equals the AC of the object or if it does not have an AC, the DM determines the check based on the size or difficulty to see the object in question.  If the invisibility was created via a spell, such as {@spell Invisibility|PHB}, the DC equals the Spell Save DC of the caster.

To see through an illusion depends on the illusion itself. If the illusion is a spell, such as {@spell Disguise Self|PHB}, the DC equals the Spell Save DC of the caster of the spell. If the illusion is made via other means, the DM determines the DC based on the circumstances of the illusion.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
{@i Note: A transmutation spell, such as Polymorph, is not merely an illusion but an actual transformation and you cannot see its true form in the current state of this ability.}

subclassFeature.name: Improved Witch's Sight
entries: {@i 6th-level The Blood Witch feature}

As an action, you can spend a use of your Eyes of The Blood Witch feature to instead cast {@spell See Invisibility|PHB} without expending a spell slot or requiring material components. When cast in this way, the spell instead lasts for a minute instead of an hour.

subclassFeature.name: Sacrificial Spells
entries: {@i 10th-level The Blood Witch feature}

Using your blood magic, you can cast spells using your own vitality rather than through your pact magic. When you cast a warlock spell, instead of spending a spell slot you can instead spend a number of hemomancy dice equal to the level you cast the spell. You can cast the spell at its original level, or to a maximum level equal to your Warlock Spell Slot. The damage you take from your hemomancy dice when spent in this way is doubled.

subclassFeature.name: Emissary of The Blood Witch
entries: {@i 14th-level The Blood Witch feature}

The first time you use your Eyes of The Blood Witch feature, you instead cast the {@spell True Seeing|PHB} spell without expending a spell slot or requiring material components, but you can only target yourself. It lasts for its full duration and cannot be dispelled. Once you reach 15th level, you also gain the {@optfeature Witch Sight|PHB} Eldritch Invocation, but it does not count against your total number of Eldritch Invocations.
In addition, the following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Potent Blood Magic
entries: When you cast a spell using a Warlock spell slot, you can spend a hemomancy die to force every creature affected by the spell to take necrotic damage equal to the number rolled plus your charisma modifier.

entries.name: Blood Magic Reserves
entries: When you have no remaining hemomancy dice, as a bonus action you can spend a warlock spell slot to regain 5 hemomancy dice. You can use the ability twice, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Four Elements
entries: You follow a monastic tradition that teaches you to harness the elements. When you focus your ki, you can align yourself with the forces of creation and bend the four elements to your will, using them as an extension of your body. Some members of this tradition dedicate themselves to a single element, but others weave the elements together.
Many monks of this tradition tattoo their bodies with representations of their ki powers, commonly imagined as coiling dragons, but also as phoenixes, fish, plants, mountains, and cresting waves.

subclassFeature.name: Disciple of the Elements
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn magical disciplines that harness the power of the four elements. A discipline requires you to spend ki points each time you use it.
You know the Elemental Attunement discipline and two other elemental disciplines of your choice. You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice at 6th, 11th, and 17th level.
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can also replace one elemental discipline that you already know with a different discipline.

entries.name: Casting Elemental Spells
entries: Some elemental disciplines allow you to cast spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} of the Player's Handbook for the general rules of spellcasting. To cast one of these spells, you use its casting time and other rules, but you don't need to provide material components for it.

Once you reach 5th level in this class, you can spend additional ki points to increase the level of an elemental discipline spell that you cast, provided that the spell has an enhanced effect at a higher level, as {@spell burning hands} does. The spell's level increases by 1 for each additional ki point you spend. For example, if you are a 5th-level monk and use Sweeping Cinder Strike to cast {@spell burning hands}, you can spend 3 ki points to cast it as a 2nd-level spell (the discipline's base cost of 2 ki points plus 1).

The maximum number of ki points you can spend to cast a spell in this way (including its base ki point cost and any additional ki points you spend to increase its level) is determined by your monk level, as shown in the Spells and Ki Points table. At 5th level, you may spend up to 3 ki points; this increases to 4 ki points at 9th level, 5 at 13th level, and 6 at 17th level.

entries.caption: Spells and Ki Points
colLabels: Maximum Ki Points for a Spell

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Form
entries: Also at 3rd level when you take the attack action, you can choose to enter an elemental form, which lasts for 1 minute, by spending a ki point. When you enter an elemental form, choose either Air, Earth, Fire, or Water. You gain one of the following benefits while your Elemental Form is active:

entries.name: Air
entries: Light like a feather, a leaf on the wind. Your reach for your melee attacks using unarmed strikes or monk weapons is increased by 5 feet and you can use your Wisdom score in place of your Strength when determining how far or how high you can jump.

entries.name: Earth
entries: Stubborn like stone and unmoving like boulders. You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks and have advantage on ability checks and saving throws made to resist being pushed back or knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Power erupts from your body and is focused onto your fists and weapons. Your unarmed strikes and monk weapons deal fire damage instead of its normal damage type. In addition, you have resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Water
entries: You are unfettered by the oceanic tides. While your feet are submerged in water, your movement speed is increased by 10 feet and swimming does not cost you any additional movement. In addition you have resistance to cold damage.

In addition to these benefits, while your chosen Elemental Form is active, disciplines that associate with said element costs 1 less ki for the initial cost of the discipline, to a minimum cost of 1 ki point. For example, while your Elemental Form is active and you are using your Fire Form and you use Sweeping Cinder Strike to cast {@spell burning hands}, you can spend 1 ki point instead of its base cost of 2.
You can only have the benefits of one chosen element at any given time, however you can change the benefits of your Elemental Form when you take the attack action by spending an additional ki point.

Your elemental form requires concentration which acts as if you were concentrating on a spell. If an elemental discipline casts a spell that requires concentration, you maintain concentration on both that spell and your elemental form. Losing concentration on either one breaks concentration on the other.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Disciplines
entries: The elemental disciplines are presented in alphabetical order. If a discipline requires a level, you must be the level in this class to learn the discipline.

entries.name: Breathtaking Dance (20th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 6 ki points to cast {@spell suffocating sphere|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: Clench of the North Wind (6th Level Required)
Dance of Fiery Dragons (20th level required)
entries: You can spend 6 ki points to cast {@spell fire storm}.

entries.name: Flames of the Phoenix (11th Level Required)
Gong of the Summit (6th Level Required)
Direct the Thunderstorm (11th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 4 ki points to cast {@spell lightning bolt}.

entries.name: Ride the Waves (6th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 3 ki to cast {@spell slipstream|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: River of Hungry Flame (17th Level Required)
Rolling Stone (6th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 3 ki to cast {@spell boulder bash|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: Slapping Waves
entries: You can spend 2 ki to cast {@spell water whack|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: Step of Giants
entries: You can spend 2 ki to cast {@spell thunderstomp|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: Waterfall of the Elders (6th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 3 ki to cast {@spell whelm|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: Wave of Rolling Earth (17th Level Required)
Whirlwind Ballet (11th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 4 ki to cast {@spell cyclone|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Elemental Discipline
entries: You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Focus
entries: At 6th level, you’ve put focus and practice into one particular element. When you finish a long rest, choose either Air, Earth, Fire, or Water. Depending on your choice, you gain one of the following benefits which ends the next time you finish a long rest and you can choose a different benefit or regain the one that ended:

entries.name: Air
entries: Your body becomes unfettered by the ground beneath your feet. You gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed and can hover, however if you end your turn airborne you slowly descend 60 feet and either safely touch the ground or end your turn falling.

entries.name: Earth
entries: Attuned to the earth beneath you, you’ve hardened your body to be sturdier. Your current and maximum hit points are increased by an amount equal to your Monk level.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Flames burn from within your soul and allow you to turn your foes to ash. Once per turn, when you hit with an unarmed strike or monk weapon you can add an additional amount of fire damage equal to your martial arts die.

entries.name: Water
entries: Fluid like the river, your movements through water are effortless and your body adapts to underwater environments. You have a swimming speed equal to your walking speed and can breathe underwater as you do air. In addition, as a bonus action you can use extreme focus to stand perfectly still on water not falling through it as you normally would. This extreme focus ends when you take damage or when you move.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Elemental Discipline
entries: You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Elementalist
entries: At 11th level, you’ve heightened your control over the elements granting you unique abilities depending on your Elemental Focus. While your Elemental Focus is active, you can cast one of the following spells without requiring material components or spending a spell slot or kit points depending on which element you chose:

subclassFeature.name: Extra Elemental Discipline
entries: You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Master of The Elements
entries: At 17th level you’ve attained absolute mastery over your elemental techniques. Choose one of your Elemental Disciplines. You can use that discipline as if you spent the minimum required ki point cost without expending any ki.
In addition, while your Elemental Focus is active you gain one of the following benefits depending on the element you chose:

entries.name: Air
entries: When you take the attack action using a monk weapon or unarmed strike, you can use the shove action as part of the attack action. In addition, you no longer descend at the end of your turn while flying.

entries.name: Earth
entries: Once per turn, when you take damage from an attack you can reduce that damage by an amount equal to your martial arts die.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Whenever you deal fire damage, you add a bonus to one of the damage rolls equal to your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Water
entries: While your feet are submerged in water your speed is doubled. In addition, you have advantage on attack rolls against a creature who does not have a swim speed while initiated in underwater combat.

In addition, you can use your action and spend 6 ki points to cast {@spell Investiture of Flame|XGE}, {@spell Investiture of Ice|XGE}, {@spell Investiture of Stone|XGE}, {@spell Investiture of Water|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, or {@spell Investiture of Wind|XGE}. Once you’ve cast one of these spells, you cannot cast any of these spells again until you have completed a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Soul
entries: Born with powers of primordial elders, you’ve mastered magic that revolves around the elements. The earth beneath your feet erecting from the ground in pillars of stone, the scorching hot flames wreathing off your body burning your foes, coiling water veiling you with a protective barrier, or commanding the wind around you to keep enemies at bay.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Magic
entries: Your knowledge of the elemental planes expands your magical capabilities. You learn spells at certain levels based on an associated element, as detailed on the table below. Once you gain access to one of these spells, it counts as a sorcerer spell for you and does not count towards your number of spells known.
Each of these spells can be swapped for a different elemental spell of the same type and same level by approval of your DM.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Form
entries: Also at 1st level, when you cast a spell from your Primordial Magic feature, you can instantly transform into an embodiment of the element you chose. You appear as an Elemental from that particular plane, for example if you chose Fire then your body would wreathe in flames and your eyes would glow like burning coals.

While in this primordial form, you gain a bonus to damage rolls related to your chosen element equal to your charisma modifier. Elements such as air, earth, or water are vague about what constitutes associated elements. Best rule of thumb, your DM has the final say, however air could include spells that use thunder or lightning, but not all spells. Whereas earth, water, and air can all be associated with bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing depending on the spell. Regardless, all the spells listed for your chosen element in your Primordial Magic feature will associate with your chosen element.
In addition, when you enter your primordial form you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your sorcerer level plus your charisma modifier.
You remain in this primordial form for 1 minute and once you enter this form you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.
Also, you know how to speak, read, and write Primordial.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Resistance
entries: Starting at 6th level, you gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage while your Primordial Form is active.
In addition, you always have resistance to a certain damage type based on the element you chose regardless if your primordial form is active or not:

entries.name: Air
entries: You gain resistance to thunder damage.

entries.name: Earth
entries: You gain resistance to acid damage.

entries.name: Fire
entries: You gain resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Water
entries: You gain resistance to cold damage.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Essence
entries: Also at 6th level, when you use a metamagic option on a spell from your Primordial Magic feature, you can regain 1d6 hit points per sorcery point spent on the metamagic option for the spell. You can only gain this magical healing once a round.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Evolution
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can enter your Primordial Form as an action by spending 5 sorcery points. Your Primordial Form now lasts for an hour rather than a minute when you use it in this way. While in your Primordial Form you gain certain benefits depending on the element you chose:

entries.name: Air
entries: You have a magical flying speed of 60 feet and you can hover. In addition, you can pass through spaces as narrow as 1 inch, so long as air can pass through it.

entries.name: Earth
entries: At the start of each of your turns, so long as your feet are touching the ground, you can gain temporary hit points equal to your Charisma modifier. In addition, you have tremorsense out to a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Flames erupt from your body whenever you’re in danger, scolding anyone who dares strike you. When a creature within 60 feet of you deals damage to you from an attack, they take 1d10 fire damage.

entries.name: Water
entries: You have a magical swim speed of 60 feet, can breathe underwater as you do air, and while fully submerged in water you can use a bonus action to teleport up to 60 feet to another space that is also underwater.

subclassFeature.name: Elder Elemental
entries: At 18th level, your very being permanently changes as you ascend to the peak of your elemental ancestry. You are always under the effects of your Primordial Form and can shift your appearance to appear as your natural self or your primordial self.
The temporary hit points you’d originally receive when you would enter your primordial form instead are gained after you finish a short or long rest.
In addition, the spell you gained at 1st level from your Primordial Magic feature can be cast at its lowest level without expending a spell slot or requiring material components.

subclassFeature.name: College Of The Elemental Dancer
entries: A true master of elements shifts between them, effortlessly and elegantly. As fluid with their movements as a flowing river, as hard to hit as a feather riding the wind, hits as hard as a flying rock, and as hot as flames when need be.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Dance
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can expend a use of your bardic inspiration to begin an elemental dance which lasts for 1 minute. During this time, choose a tempo from air, earth, fire, or water.  You gain one of the following benefits depending on what you chose, and you can shift your chosen element as a bonus action on subsequent turns:

entries.caption: Elemental Dance Table
rows: Your movement speed is increased by 10 feet and you can hover up to a foot off the ground effortlessly. You can cast the {@spell cutting wind|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you.

Your body becomes tough as stone, you have resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage and you can cast the {@spell magic stone|XGE} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you.
You can cast the {@spell fire bolt} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you, and your weapon attacks deal an extra amount of fire damage equal to your bardic inspiration die.

You can walk across the surface of water as you would solid ground, however you still fall through the water if you end your turn there. You can cast the {@spell water splash|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Tongue
entries: Also at 3rd level, your extensive knowledge on the elemental planes makes you an expert in conversing with said elementals. You know how to speak, read, and write Primordial. If you already have Primordial, you can instead choose a different language. In addition, you have advantage on Charisma ability checks made with elementals, provided you are not hostile toward them.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Inspiration
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can grant your elemental magic onto an ally while embracing it through your dance. While under the effects of your Elemental Dance, a creature with your bardic inspiration can use it to add to the damage rolls of their attacks or spells. The bonus damage is dependent on your current chosen tempo:

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Dance Improvement
entries: Also at 6th level, you gain some additional effects while in your Elemental Dance. While under the effects of your Elemental Dance, you gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Charisma modifier provided you aren't wearing medium or heavy armor or using a shield. In addition, you gain the ability to cast certain spells while using your bard spell slots while under the effects of your Elemental Dance depending on your chosen tempo, which count as bard spells for you:

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Ballet
entries: Starting at 14th level, your mastery over your primordial dancing has ascended to its peak. The first time you use your Elemental Dance feature, you do not have to spend a bardic inspiration. Every other time after the first until you finish a long rest, you spend the bardic inspiration as normal.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Conductor
entries: Also at 14th level, you’ve learned to pinpoint weakness in even the most resistant foes. When you deal damage to a creature with a resistance to acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage, you can choose to ignore their resistance until the end of the current turn.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of The Jester
entries: Filled with joy, laughter, and energy. Dancing across the battlefield with elegance and glee, skipping along the city streets with a smile. You take risks and usually expect reward, blind to your own shortcomings. But most of all, you entertain those around you with your extrovert nature.
At each indicated Fate Weaver level, add the listed spells to your spells prepared. They do not count towards your limit.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: At 1st level, you gain proficiency in rapiers, one musical instrument of your choice, and your choice of either Performance or a set of artisan tools of your choosing.

subclassFeature.name: Elusive Jester
entries: Beginning at 1st level when you choose this subclass, you know just what to say to get yourself out of a mess you more than likely got yourself into. When you make a Charisma (Persuasion) or Charisma (Deception) check, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10 by spending a fate die. When you do so, you then roll that fate die and add it to the total.

subclassFeature.name: Inspiring Performance
entries: At 6th level, you’ve become an inspiring performer that manages to put a smile on creatures at just the right time and boost their confidence in their own abilities. If you spend at least 10 minutes making an artistic performance, you can grant a number of creatures equal to your Charisma modifier temporary hit points equal to your level.
In addition, for the next 8 hours, creatures who benefited from this feature have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.
Once you use this feature, you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Skillful Jester
entries: At 10th level, you have always kept your mind open to trying new things and can pick up skills on the fly. When you finish a long rest, choose any one skill of which you are not proficient in. You add half of your proficiency bonus to any ability checks using that skill until you next finish a long rest, after which you can choose the same skill or a different skill to gain this benefit.

subclassFeature.name: Expertise
entries: Also at 10th level, choose two of your skill or tool proficiencies. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies. At 18th level, you choose two more of your skill or tool proficiencies to gain this benefit.

subclassFeature.name: Boon of the Jester
entries: At 14th level, you take unnecessary risks to get what you want or maybe just to have fun. As a reaction whenever you make an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw you can choose to roll at disadvantage instead by spending a fate die. You cannot benefit from any advantages when you do so. Also, you roll the fate die and add it to the roll. If you succeed, you automatically receive the best outcome of the result treating the d20 roll as a 20. On a failure, you automatically receive the worst possible outcome, treating the d20 roll as a 1 and doubling any damage dealt to you as a result if you were to take any.
You have a number of uses of this feature equal to your Charisma modifier, regaining all expended uses after a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Jester of the Weave
entries: At 18th level, your ability to enthrall others with your performance becomes legendary. Whenever you make a Charisma (Performance) check, or an ability check using an artisan’s tools, you can spend 2 fate dice to automatically treat the d20 roll as a 20. You must choose to do this before the roll.
You have a number of uses of this feature equal to your Charisma modifier, regaining all expended uses after a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Phoenix
entries: Your power draws from the immortal flame that fuels the legendary phoenix. You or your ancestors perhaps rendered a phoenix a great service, or you were born in its presence. Whatever the cause, a shard of the phoenix's power dwells within you.

That power is a mixed blessing. Like the mythical creature, you can invoke fiery energy and gain the ability to cheat death itself. This power comes at a cost. The fire within you seethes, demanding to be unleashed. You sometimes find yourself absentmindedly feeding fires. You can't bear to allow a fire to sputter out. You feel most comfortable while holding a lit torch or sitting in front of a campfire.

More importantly, this gift comes with no special protection from fire. You are as vulnerable as any other creature to fiery magic, including your own. Those of this aspect can use their powers to pull themselves back from the brink of death, and all too often their own rash nature or reliance on destructive magic is what puts them there in the first place.
At each indicated Fate Weaver level, add the listed spells to your spells prepared. They do not count towards your limit.

subclassFeature.name: Ignite
entries: At 1st level, you gain the ability to start fires with a touch. You learn the {@spell Produce Flame} cantrip and it doesn’t count against your total known cantrips. If you already have this cantrip, you can choose a different cantrip from the Fate Weaver spellcasting list.

Additionally, as an action, you can magically ignite a flammable object you touch with your hand—an object such as a torch, a piece of tinder, or the hem of drapes. The object cannot be worn or carried by anyone other than you when you do so. If you choose, the object can take fire damage equal to your proficiency bonus, and continue to do so at the start of each of your subsequent turns thereafter.
A creature may use their action to put out the flames on the object, or you may choose to put out the flames (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of the Phoenix
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can unleash the phoenix fire that blazes within you.

As a bonus action by spending a fate die, you magically wreathe yourself in swirling fire, as your eyes glow like hot coals. For 1 minute you gain the following benefits and you can spend another fate die as a bonus action to prolong your Mantle of the Phoenix for an additional minute:

items: You shed bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet.
Any creature takes fire damage equal to your proficiency bonus if it hits you with a melee attack from within 5 feet of you or if it touches you.
Whenever you roll fire damage on your turn, the roll gains a bonus equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Flames of Rebirth
entries: Starting at 6th level, the fiery energy within you grows restless and vengeful. In the face of defeat, it surges outward to preserve you in a fiery roar.

If you are reduced to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to draw on the immortal flames of the phoenix. You are instead reduced to 1 hit point, and each creature within 10 feet of you takes fire damage equal to four rolls of your fate dice.
If you use this feature while under the effects of your Mantle of the Phoenix, this feature gains a bonus to its fire damage equal to your fate weaver level.
You can use this feature once, regaining the ability to do so when you finish a long rest or if you spend a use of your Spell Weaving feature to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Fueling the Fire
entries: Starting at 10th level, if your Mantle of the Phoenix would end, as a reaction you can spend a hit die as if you were regaining hit points during a short rest. Instead of healing, you take damage equal to what you roll, and the duration of your mantle increases by a number of rounds equal to half the damage you took plus one round (to a minimum of 2 rounds). This damage cannot be reduced by any means.

When you use this feature, your body becomes scorched with burn marks as dark as coals. When your Mantle of the Phoenix ends, you gain a level of exhaustion for each time you use this feature that can only be removed when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Boon of the Phoenix
entries: At 14th level, you learn the {@spell fire storm} and {@spell investiture of flame|XGE} spells and they do not count against your total number of prepared spells. When you cast either of these spells, you instantly enter your Mantle of the Phoenix (no action required) and without spending a fate die.

subclassFeature.name: Form of the Phoenix
entries: At 18th level, you finally master the spark of fire that dances within you. While under the effect of your Mantle of Phoenix feature, you gain additional benefits:

items: Fiery wings sprout out from your back, granting you the ability to magically fly. You have a flying speed of 60 feet and can hover. Movement from this magical flight does not provoke opportunity attacks.
Once per turn whenever you cast a spell that deals fire damage, you can choose to ignore resistances and immunity to fire damage for that spell until the end of the current turn.

Your body becomes more akin to the fiery elemental your powers are drawn from. You can occupy a creature’s space and vice versa. Whenever a creature starts its turn whilst occupying your space, it takes fire damage equal to two rolls of your fate die.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Moon
entries: You are normally calm and serene. You chose to walk down the path not of violence, not of bloodshed, but of healing. You are the calming sound of the ocean tides, you are the moonlight that heals wounds as weakened ones rest. People look up to you as your presence is soft and calming.

entries.caption: Aspect Spells
rows: {@spell beacon of hope}, {@spell mass healing word}

subclassFeature.name: Healing Light
entries: Starting at 1st level, whenever you use a spell of 1st level or higher to restore hit points to a creature, the creature regains additional hit points equal to 1 plus your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Barrier of Moonlight
entries: Starting at 6th level, by performing a 10 minute ritual you can cast the spell Tiny Hut as a ritual spell.
